reviewText:
this game is actually way too good for the rpg genre. it has great magic, fighthing and character development systems. it has horse riding and sailing, platform jumping, sneaking, thieving, assassinations, huge dungeons, caves, many monsters and items for loot etc etc...

but unfortunately it is an incomplete game. most prolly it's developer ran out of money in the project and had to release it prematurely. more than half of the maps are deserted! no loot, no monsters, no missions, nothing. you run around hoping to see some things but mostly it's just empty terrain...

nevertheless it is a very good and stable game with more than 50hrs of game play for average rpg fan...

would i recommend it? no, not in it's premature state...

but do get it if you find it under some steam sales. it's definitly worth it...

reviewText:
Normally my opinion is very standard and mainstream so 99% of the time I agree when a game has many negative reviews. This time I cannot agree because the first hours I started this game I had so much fun.
It reminds me of Ultima and Morrowind. The world is really open and huge and even if you follow the main story you have plenty of possibilties to explore on your own.
Direct from the beginning you can have a huge profit if you start reading the books and looting the chests you find and the artwork is really stunning even for todays standards.
The opening cinematic is really nice and made you feel really part of the world.

The crafting system is fun because useless items give you resources and this resources you can use to upgrade your valueable items.
Like in Morrowind you can develop your character while you play and you are not restricted to only one class.
If you read the turorial messages it give you all information about key bindings and while it's sometimes annoying at the beginning to make your character do what you want him/her to do, but like in real life after some practice you become comfortable with it.

There is a lot of character interaction, but it never gets annoying because you don't  have to read pages of gossip.
If you want more information about subjects you can read the books or buy the strategy guides on Steam.

I bought the game long time ago before it was on sales on Steam and don't regret. I bought the strategy guides now just to tell the devs I really like this game.

Most important of all is that I really think the devs have passion for their project and that's what you can see in every single part of the game. I don't understand people rating this so negative without explaining what is so wrong about the game just because they were asked for their profile when starting the game. Get over it.

If you like exploring every part of the world in your own story with your own character doing what you like to do and want a huge adventure with fighting monsters and explore secrets don't think twice to get this chem now when it's on sale.

reviewText:
I'm happy to say that this game is a HUGE improvement over the first Two Worlds game.

First, let me say the bad news:

The combat is still kinda ♥♥♥♥♥♥, but not so horrible that you can't enjoy the game. Sometimes, the combat is an absolute joy because it is a tad wonkly and I had many laughs because of it.
Horses still suck AND there's no horse combat. Not even one step forward, huh? 2 steps back and that's it. Meh.
Visuals are fine, but some character models are just gross.
Voice overs still suck, but who cares.
UI kinda sucks, but it's usable. Hell, I think MechWarrior's UI 2.0 is just fine, so take my opinion for what it's worth.
Still a ton of bugs, just like Two Worlds I.

Now the good.

HUGE improvements on everything, even on the things that still kinda suck. Within the context of this series, that's a good thing. At least they learned.
OH MY GOD the magic! The combos for magic, warrior abilities, and archer/thief stuff is great. SO MANY POSSIBILITIES. I dig that, I really do.
Big map, lots of baddies to kill. I like.
The teleportation system is 10x better and more reminiscent of something out of TES. That's a good design, keep it, it works.
And the quest system is great and the story is...eh, not so horrible. It's not great, but it'll do.
Character customization is waaaay better, and that's good. However you still can't make a female in single player mode, DAFUQ, TopWare?

All in all, I give it a 6.5/10 would probably bang again.

reviewText:
Two Worlds II is your typical fantasy adventure/RPG game with loads of enemies, challenges, things to do, average story-telling & plot, mediocre graphics and a very grindy multiplayer. However.. Even though this game has got some flaws it does deliver on some areas which makes it all worth the while.

As far as the single-player story goes it's nothing special, really. It's very generic and the character you play as is very easy to forget about (lacking background-story, no real connection). None of the main characters really stand out. Instead, those who you talk to once in a while are those with the most memorable dialog and unique sense of humour - which is a neat change of pace.

When you venture out in the singleplayer world it's easy to let go of what you were doing and just hunt for enemies only to use your skills, no matter what you specialize in at the time whether it be magic, archery, melee combat or all three. They are all equally as fun to play, even though the magic-system in this game is by far the most worked on.

You conjure your own spells by using cards which you can combine in almost any way you can think of. You can create spells which summon creatures to fight for you, spells which summon tornados which in turn summons heavy steel anvils - at the same time as it's spinning around throwing the anvils all around the place. Or if you're more into projectiles you can create spells which shoot out several projectiles that are either homing or simply bounces through target to target hitting multiple enemies with only one projectile. OR; combine it all - projectile -> anvile summoning -> Tornado. Great fun!

However, this game is not only about singleplayer, even though it's great fun. You can also join your friends on Multiplayer where the game turns into somewhat of a grind-fest and all you do - basically - is repeat mission in order to gain levels and increase the strength of your character. Yes, it's tedious.. But with the right people the multiplayer turns into a very much appreciated hang-out. You have several game-modes ranging from the typical story-mission style to sruvival and even town-management. Yes, you can build your bery own town/village and you have to manage it in order to keep your villagers happy. And you friends can join you in your village, to either help you out when you need to defend it or to see how you manage your village compared to theirs.

There's also PvP in this game, but my experience with the PvP has been very bad which in the long run made me ignore it completely, so I'm not gonna comment on it.


All in all it's a great game. The graphics are very dated since the game is old, but even though it looks bad" it still delivers on key points; massive world(s)

reviewText:
When you first start playing, the jerky camera work and non-intuitive movement/combat system might make you want to stop playing...you should follow that instinct.

After you get through the interface's learning curve, you stumble on to an actually decent action-RPG. Think Gothic but without interesting characters or a world that makes you care about. While I realize that's not a glowing recommendation, most of the game is actually enjoyable. The side-quests are interesting, and there are some genuinely funny moments. Unfortunately, you're never really *in* the game, because conversations are abysmal. The voice-acting is very poor, as are the conversation animations. You have to constantly refer to your journal for synopses, because the in-game dialogue is sometimes borderline nonsensical and leaves one wondering what actually just happened.

All that aside, it's perfectly possible to get tens of hours of solid gameplay out of this title...until you come to the final boss. I won't offer spoilers, but I will say that the mechanics of the final boss fight essentially toss aside all of the character building you've worked towards. The RPG elements die, only to be replaced by a clunky FPS/potion management test. Due to the game's refusal to let you save during the final battle, you will also be subjected to the final cutscreen each re-try (and there will be many, many re-tries if you actually want to win).

In other words, it starts out clunky, gets decent without ever being really good, and then ends with the least enjoyable boss fight I've ever encountered in a game.

I suppose the good news is that the characters are so unrelateable and uninteresting that I never felt compelled to power-through and beat the final boss, so on the positive side, at least you don't feel like you've lost too much if you never find out how the story ends.

If you have to play the game, just stop at the final boss and look online for a final cutscreen.

reviewText:
+ LOTS of content
+ Gorgeous world design
+ The voice acting is bad (especially the main character's), but amusing at times
+ One of the most interesting crafting systems (including magic) I've ever seen in an RPG
+ Multiplayer has an interesting management mode
+ Sailing mechanics are polished
+ Challenging (due to some negative aspects, so take that part with a grain of salt)

- Awful character models
- Combat is clunky for a game of its generation
- Combat feels unbalanced due to its clunkiness
- Interface is not user friendly
- Unoriginal and uninspiring plot and characters
- Character creation with both genders and different races is only available on multiplayer
- Game forces you to romance women and be a shameful womanizer
- Horse riding
- No tutorials for some important aspects, such as the hotkeys

Verdict: This is actually my second review for this game. I feel like many people didn't understand my first, so here's a second one, more simple to understand. First of all, yes, Two Worlds 2 is not a polished game. Is not your Bethesda RPG (although their games are still very buggy, the mechanics are solid), nor it tries to be. TW2 is awful in many aspects, but it shines in others and it can be a very enjoyable experience if you can deal with its flaws. It does its own thing and it's good enough at it, being 100% worth the PRICE AT DISCOUNTS (I think I paid something around USD4,00 for the Velvet Edition). I wouldn't recommend it at full price, but for more than 30h of gameplay to explore such an interesting and beautiful world, it certainly is worth the bargain I paid for it.

Oh, and btw! The DRM is not as concerning as some people put it. It is offensive, but you DO NOT have to give accurate information (I didn't and it worked out alright). Just put something random there, or skip it entirely (yes, you don't have to go through that at all if you don't like it). In all honestly, there are worse DRMs to be worried about out there, like Denuvo, whatever Blizzard uses in Diablo 3 and whatever EA has and will use.

reviewText:
Well I was pleasantly surprised. There is a lot going for this game and it really is an improvement on the first game in the series.
I thought the main character was a hoot. I loved the very dry but funny comments he made throughout the game. I liked the side quests, they were interesting and entertaining and usually quite unpredictable in how they would turn out.
I enjoyed the storyline, I certainly didn't want to stop playing until I got to the end and I was tempted to do a lot of side missions along the way.
The horses were a bit of a fail (never around) as was fighting in the small corridors. Terrible camera angles meant I couldn't always see my character at all and he was getting stuck in corners and having the stuffing pummelled out of him while I blindly tried pressing keys trying to get him up and away from walls, corners or holes.
The inventory was a bit of a mess, the idea of armour sets nice but it was too easy to dismantle an item and then when you switch armour sets find yourself left standing in the nuddy with only your bow and a small dagger. (Hehe)(Pun intended)

I will say this. I would be replaying this game over and over if I had the option to play as a female. I wouldn't want to stop until I experienced all the classes and their armours/weapon combinations. I would also have been very interested in buying the dlc and/or any expansions. I think RPG developers should give serious consideration to us female gamers as consumers with spending power. I liked the game but playing as a male... there is no replay interest for me.

Overall I'm glad I played this game though. It was fun!

reviewText:
Two Worlds 2 is a good game, but it is not a great game. I really liked the first Two Worlds and TW2 is almost as good, but there are a few things that really bothered me.
The controls seem like they were made for a console game and at times it is rather difficult to have good control with mouse and keyboard even with customization. E.g. run, block and sneak are all on the same key, often causing confusion in the heat of battle (it is less than ideal when you are trying to get some space between you and an attacker and you end up trying to block instead).
The game also clearly seems to give meelee fighters an advantage over casters and archers. My favorite play style is that of a stealthy archer. You can not do that in this game. Sneak attacks can only be done with daggers. Archery in general is rather difficult as the auto aim can not be turned off and it does not know how to aim ahead of a moving target, causing even a high level archer to constantly miss even low level and even slow moving targets from relatively close distance. It is a bit better with sniper mode from a great distance (where auto aim does not lock), but it is really annoying nevertheless. Also there is no first person mode, so your characters elbow tends to get into the way, blocking your view of enemies.
Finally there were also quite a few bugs (dialogue skipping, and wrong shaders getting loaded occasionally, among others) that cost this game points.
On the positive side, I really enjoyed the story (which unfortunately felt a little rushed in the end) and the many side quests all of which are well written and entertaining.  The crafting system is simple and fun.
I loved the lack of classes and the freedom to customize your character skills. There is a lot to explore and discover, which is always nice. The graphics are quite good, though not outstanding for todays standards. All in all a good game for RPG players looking for something to spend some time on. I got it for a real bargain around Christmas and I would definitely recommend it for that price. I would not buy it for the full 19,90 it is costing right now, though. Better wait for another special again.

reviewText:
A very solid RPG for the most part, with a crafting system second to none. It is not without it's rough edges however, and you'll want to play it on the hardest setting to help guard against your almost Godlike attributes too early in the game. The voice-acting is cringe worthy at times, but it is ok for the most part, and the ai can be extremely predictable and too easily defeated on normal and lower difficulties.

The greatest strength of TW2 is that it get's more right than it get's wrong, and it is all packaged in very good looking graphical wrapping. It is just a blast to play - period, at least for me, and this alone should be enough for any fan of open world RPG's. Make no mistake, this is NOT Skyrim, but it is a very adequate and capable RPG that will keep you questing, looting, and killing, for dozens and dozens of hours.

Get the Velvet Edition. The DLC is spectacular, and is almost better in many regards than the base game - just not as long obviously.

Base game = 8.5/10
Velvet Edition = 9.0/10

Disclaimer:
No animal or Human was harmed in the making of this - opinion.

reviewText:
I am playing this game and just can't get enough!

Seriously, it is visually stunning.  I think it may be because they designed it for 3D.  Even though I cannot play it in 3D, I can feel the graphic design quality.
Characters are mostly well acted.
The spell system is very creative.  You can combine different modifiers that custom alter your spells, but many times applying the alterations creates completely different spells altogether.
The game allows you to quickly switch between three different outfits with the touch of a button.  I didn't think I would like this at first, but it allows me to play warrior, mage, and archer/sneak as the situation allows.  I have specialized gear for all three roles and it actually works.
It has really creative quests without being the go and fetch variety.  When the rare occasion of running errands arises, the story line has a compelling reason and makes you want to do it.
If you like old-school, dark, un-mapping (as in you need graph paper) dungeons, there is  a unique challenge in chapter one that lets you try your hand at it.  It is not necessary for the story line, so that is optional.
I'm a huge fan of Morrowind, Oblivion, and Skyrim.  It's no Elder Scrolls, but I would give it a 90/100.
Whatever bugs existed at release have been smoothed out for the Steam version and the game hasn't given me a single problem for over 70 hours of play.

And it is huge!  I am in the middle of the second chapter with much left to go.  I am a person that does every little quest, so I figure I have about 100 hours left in this thing.

I have no idea why I never heard of this game and don't hear people talking about it.

Have fun with this hidden treasure!

reviewText:
<please ignore my playtime, i played abut 100 hours more during an internet downtime>

Two Worlds II is one of my all time favourite RPG's.
You can choose the way you want your character, and the way you want to evolve. You can become a mace wielding mage or a bow using berserker - its totally up to you!

The playable areas are huge - very huge. You can scout and kill every area you like, enter any of the dungeons you find (except for a very few where you need a key for).
The main quest line is very comprehensive, there are countless side quest and a huge amount of dungeons. While the story might not be the best you have experienced, it is still interesting and made me want to play more and more and more.

The game includes a ton of different kind of weapons, spells and skills. Again, its totally up to the player to choose which of these he wants to learn/use. The combat is quite basic, but fun nontheless.

A few downsides:
- requires registration
- takes away your rl
- graphic pretty old for todays standards (still enjoyable)
- the Multiplayer is a) dead and b) bad

Overall, i still recommend this game.

(one of the best parts: The Labyrinth side quests. Looking for the tomb inside a labyrinth, only equipped with.... either a weapon or a torchlight. There is no light source anywhere to be found. You need to finish about 10 of those. Totally awesome)

reviewText:
Massively addictive game. Cannot get enough of it, something about upgrading weapons, armor & gems just keeps me interested. The combat system, when you get used to it, is very rewarding and fun - while I still face some challenges I do feel like a badass now that I have properly levelled up and use the right gems, armor and weapons. Decided to go full warrior class so packed everything into strength and a little into endurance.

Pros:
1. The quests are WAY more interesting than some of the typical RPG quests with some pretty entertaining and, dare I say, mature storylines.
2. The graphics & sound is absolutely remarkable.
3. Variety of things to do i.e. tomb raiding, fighting, hunting, horse riding, sailing, upgrading items, shopping etc. (keeps me entertained for long periods of time).
4. As stated in my opening remarks, the combat system is fantastic and if attacks are timed with defense the results are some excellent fighting routines. The enemies also have certain defense such as blunt force vs cutting damage so when facing say a Skeleton it is better to use a hammer than a sword. It is important to see / know what your enemies are immune to" so changing weapons is a must to quickly end fights

reviewText:
I bought this game for 0,52 EUR and I was pleasantly surprised how good this game actually is.
Pros:
- sophisticated game mechanics (magic, crafting, etc,... )
- pretty neat graphic visuals, a lot of objects reacts to physics which is nice touch
- magic crafting is really interesting and creating your own spells is fun
- multiplayer (but have some cons), you can own a village thats a pretty interesting feature too
- interesting locations, nice level design
- you can have a boat

Cons:
- controls arent that great character doesnt responde always that how would you thought
- multiple actions are set on one button which leads to unwanted deaths because instead of running you character starts sneaking (but you will get used to it)
- multiplayer - have no open world so you can only play adventures and after that there is not much to do ( there is a really lost potential in MP )
- open world with restriction, You're on islands and you have to complete certain quests to get to the next island
- not really interesting story

Summary:
Two Worlds II is a great game with a huge potencial that was kinda wasted. But still it is a game where you can spend many hours and having fun. Also you can try multiplayer with you friends which also offers a lot of hours of fun. So far I can highly recommend it.

reviewText:
Decided to give the game a chance after all positive reviews, and it was worth it. Overall well-executed and solid (not what you would expect of Two Worlds franchise, huh?) Though it has it downsides, of that below. But short summary - yes, the game is good.

Two Worlds 2 in many ways reminds me of Gothic series. Free roaming, ability to climb rocks, ability to beat strong enemies, loot and steal everything, sensible NPCs and a right feel of progression. Not exactly there, but this is the best experience in open-world RPGs I've got since those times. On top of that, excellent graphics and animations (oh, pity that with such great combat animations game has such crappy combat mechanics!) and good story and side quests - you feel involved and always have a reason to intervene.

Bad things. 1) The redundant key entering and invasive registration form (do not fill that, it's unnecessary!). Almost ragequite after some unsuccesful registration attempts; thankfully, continued. No drm-client, at least. 2) The game claims to be open-world, but in fact you are limited to plot zones, though they are large and free to roam. And there is next to nothing to explore outside of key locations. So it's more correct to perceive this game as story-driven RPG, but without rails and corridors. 3) Game is exploitable in a lot of ways. Kiting, click spamming, paralizing, poor aggro handling, patrol limits - all of that makes combat unchallengeable and boring. Having tons of health of the enemies doesn't help with boring. Heard there are mods that improve combat and difficulty level, but haven't tried them.

Overall, the game was fun. Little grindy, but I don't mind to kite mobs a little - loot is good as a reward. Good controls, freedom to go, believable world, good story and quests. Good thing I have an addon, can experience the game a little more.

And, of course, 10/10 for being eaten by umbrella!

reviewText:
While not the greatest game out, it took me by surprise. I purchased an RPG bundle because of a game in the mix that I thought looked enjoyable, Two Worlds II came with it and the videos looked alright.

I have quite a bit of experience when it comes to RPGs and gaming in general working on developing my own games, software, etc.. over the years. If I could change one purchase I made at full price, I would've pre-ordered this game at full price rather than buy Arcania ( Gothic 4 ) on pre-order; never again from that company. Gothic 4 is one of the worst games, it is so full of bugs that you can't even walk down a small slope because you keep hitting invisible walls that stops you befor letting you continue. Two Worlds II is actually quite refined.

I haven't played it in a while, but I ended up buying it 3 times ( One bundle had the standard edition, and the Pirates DLC, and then I bought another bundle with the Epic edition, then once for a friend because I enjoyed it so much ). I'd buy it again.

There are a few downsides to the game, but they're so minimal I can't even remember them.

This game seems very polished, I may have encountered a bug that I couldn't replicate. Gameplay is smooth, combat is simple when you get used to it, the controls don't feel clunky like Gothic 4 ( where you can spam pick-up and the character does 20 squats before picking up the item and where hitting enemies is a chore ).

I'd rate this to be almost as much fun as Skyrim. The game has plenty of side-quests, twists, and more. I don't recall whether or not I cleared out 100% of the game, but at over 100 hours of time in game says something. The price I paid wouldn't have even gotten me a movie ticket, or a popcorn at the movies, at that was with buying it 3 times; For a game from 2011, it definitely plays quite well.

If you think the price of a few coffees, a movie ticket, or a few soft-drinks is worth it, consider the cost to entertainment value for a game like this and buy it. If you're on the fence about the $20 price-tag, wait until it is on sale ( the bundle sites still have it too at a steal ) but at $10, it is more than worth it.

voteText: 63 of 108 people (58%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Heck yes I recommend this game. I actually believe that I would still be happy if I payed the full 20 dollars for Two worlds 2.

So let's hear the primary complains

DRM
Uncheck the box, type in the code once. Done. No problem, no hassle

Voice acting
The one thing I really love about this game is that every voice actor is different (or almost all). It's like I'm really in a living breathing world as everyone sounds unique. In the real world, not everyone is a great orator either. Some people are shy, some people mumble, some people are annoying, some people are goofy, some are awkward, some are confident. This game captures all of this aspect.
Unlike skyrim and oblivion where every NPC has a golden radio voice, with imperfection lies a certain charm that can't be seen in other games.

Story
I didn't finish the story yet, but it's not bad. Open world games aren't really known for great stories anyways.

Side quests
Every side quest is unique, and there is an abundance of it. They do go in depth and there are species areas allocated just for the quests instead of plain backtracking.

Combat
Okay, there is actually a problem here. The swordfighting is clunky. You have to not press any directional button to initiate combos and sometimes the hitboxes are way off. That is a genuine flaw.
Archery is wack. It doesn't feel satisfying and the hits of the arrow seem shallow.

However, the magic spell crafting portion of the game is amazing. 4000 combinations of spells and great varying effects of each unique permutations make magic combat great. The others not so much

There you have it. If you see it on a sale I would definitely recommend a try since it dips below $5 (and often 3$)

reviewText:
Don't let my time played fool you, I played the ♥♥♥♥ out of this on the Xbox. I would get into all the cool mechanics, the odd sense of humor, the vast amount of content, the crafting system, and the frankly insane magic system. But to be honest, I'm really just here to get something off my chest.

For all of the game's vast scale, beautiful landscapes, absolute freedom, and good mechanics, I'm afraid despite all the time I sunk into it it never really stuck with me. The world never felt alive or like anything I was doing had impact on anything else. In short it constantly felt like I was in a game interacting with npc's, a horrific sense of disconnect that kept me from caring about anything that happened in it. It has almost a lonely feeling to it. In that sense I think it shares a ton with games like Sacred 2, where it feels like quality was sacrificed for quantity. Though, this game is WAYYYY better than Sacred 2 XD (Talk about a waste of time!) This lifeless world was really the Achilles heel that kept a good game from being a great one!

Morrowind has its incredible world that draws you in with a unique setting and music, Skyrim has some damn fine side questing and full voice acting, not to mention some incredible lore to get sucked into, and TW2.... well, doesn't really have any of that. :/

That is not to say that it's a bad game, as I said, mechanically it's a solid RPG. But if you're looking for immersion or a living breathing world, you would probably be better off buying something else. I really want to love this game because I like lesser known studios being successful, but honestly I found my time in the world only moderately entertaining.

In the end, I think my sentiments mirror Angry Joe's, if you're a HUGE RPG fan who is waiting for the next big RPG and haven't checked out TW2, you should! It does a lot of things very uniquely and has its own personal style which is worth experiencing. Unique mechanics and a quirky, slightly self aware humor are just enough to keep you soldiering on. Just don't expect to feel very engaged, maybe listen to a podcast or chat over discord while you play. XD

7/10 - Unique, a definite recommendation RPG fans burnt out on Skyrim/Witcher. Flawed, has a hard time making its setting engaging. Get it when it goes on sale.

EDIT: One thing I forgot to mention, and why I went back to review this game in the first place, is that shockingly an update is coming out for the game soon. It makes absolutely no sense, but there was an announcement of a sequel and another upcoming DLC to coincide with an engine overhaul. I think it's pretty amazing they're still updating this game! Kudos to the developers for being so dedicated, it certainly has me very curious at to what the DLC could be! So if you do buy the game, bear in mind that apparently there will be an overhaul in quarter 2 of 2016... which is really close.

reviewText: Atmospheric Action RPG.  Open world exploration, really crisp and detailed graphics on a mid level gaming rig at high settings.  Hand to hand combat is solid.  Magic is really fun, based on a card system, mix and match to create lots of different variations on spells.  Good crafting system to upgrade your equipments to higher levels and add augmentations, all are meaningfull in battle.  Plenty of quests, many interesting.  Big game with lots to do and explore, easy to get lost in.  Story is fairly generic but it works, gives you a reason to explore the vibrant world, but the exploration is what keeps you coming back.

reviewText: This was a pretty good game that could have been much better. Be sure to save allot because it crashes often because maybe I was  going to fast with the controller. No keyboard  options unless you are entering codes. Had to go back one time and lost about 5 hours of game play because of a glich in the sequence of tasks where I ran into a loop that I could not find a way around to move forward in the game. Another time while doing a task in the swamp ran into some creatures that were part of a task which I did not have yet, then when I did, I could not do them because I had alread killed them and the tasks did not reset itself or would still be showing on my map .  Also, one thing about the free roaming aspect is, if you wander off too far from where the game thinks you should be it will send you back, even if you found a way to get their using your aquired abilites. Made it to the last boss fight and for me it was so hard to beat it using a 360 controller and gave up tring to finish it for now. Hint, fire protection a must. Maybe I will go back to before the point of no return and just play around, because, I was having fun before I did. Realy enjoyed using my sail boat for some reason and hoping to play the pirate DLC some time in the future. Check my profile info for my system spec's to compair with yours, I played it at 1080P with the settings maxed out.\n\nI would recommend this game if your into these types of games for the story line even thou technicly I have not completely finished the game, but maybe you will.

reviewText: I couldn't get even 15 minutes into the game. From clunky Dialogue to poor controls, this game has it all! The voice acting is plain awful, and isn't helped in the lines they have is just as bad. The graphics are horrible, the hair's alpha layer is messed up and looks like they have a drier sheet in their hair. The framerate can be anywhere from 60 to 10 in the blink of an eye. The controls are horrible and unresponsive at best. The combat does not feel rewarding in the slightest, you hold left mouse and you win; your attacks cancel the enemies attack animation, and you attacks cannot be staggered. The game has DRM as far as the eye can see, you have to enter several serial codes, give away your addrss, your email, your name, your computer specs to allow them to detect if it's on a different device, which will trigger the DRM if you so much as upgrade your ram or hard drive.
voteText: 11 of 16 people (69%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game takes some ♥♥♥♥ for being... mediocre which it is. Thats not to say its not fun.

-Visually its falling behind the times. Although the world and such still look pretty good characters and animations are well dated.
-Melee combat and most combat in this game is.... really like a sloppy supporting feature to allow the player to move through the world and story. (Ill get to magic l8er)

All in all the biggest issue with this game are where it sits now. As of the time Im making this review most if not all of its concepts are outdated. Unfortunately this was never a game to define an era so unless you liked it when it came out its not gonna have much for you 'now'.

+Magic. This is one of the few/only games that actually allows you to collect MANY spells and veriations that you can actually just combine almost freely. Tipecal to RPGs you need to lvl up for more effects and 'card slots'. The whole magic system is based off a card slot type system. Its not that complex but explaining it is.
+The world. Oh man... I mean it may lack the content levels we have been spoiled with in modern gaming but its still big and beautiful. You visit multiple locations and explore a varied degree of mysteries.

Look, Im not gonna butter this one up for you but if you looking for a decent RPG worth some hours of cheep fun., this may just be the game for you.
As always I suggest getting any game on sale, I stress that here as well. Its a good game but unless your jonesing for this game specificly best to snag it at a discount.

7.5/10
Watch some gameplay. If you like what you see then have some fun.

reviewText:
Well, after Two Worlds 1 my hopes were up. I should have known better.
(note: updated 02-Jun-2016 after spending far too many hours playing it to the end)

Two Worlds 2 on PC is worse in every way.  I'm barely to level 6 and I'm already annoyed as hell with this game.  When I got to level 40 or so, I was truly p i s s e d off at this game. Sheer bloody-mindedness kept me going, except for the ending. More on that later.

On the plus side, the game lets you keep playing after the ending. I like that in a game.

If you think that reviews should only be sweetness and light, stop reading here. It gets ugly.

To start with, the graphics. Even on max resolution, it has the feel of a game stuck on 640x800. Limited view, huge character in the middle of the screen, everything that's wrong with a low-resolution view but at 2560x1440. Even fiddling with the FOV doesn't really help.

Then there's the inventory tracking. TW1 let you put things where you wanted them. TW2 doesn't even pretend to care. No matter resolution (see above), the inventory screen takes up most of your screen. And instead of fitting more onto the screen, they just increased the size of the items. So you end up multiple pages of stuff you cannot sort to suit yourself, that you have to page through to find what it was they just plopped into the inventory.

Crafting? Don't make me laugh. You can upgrade" equipment
date: except you can't upgrade it very much to start
recommended: and by the time you have the level required to upgrade it to something nice
hoursPlayed: you find stuff that's better than what you can upgrade it to anyway. Then there's the material requirements. Each item drops 1
voteText: sometimes 2 of a material. However
helpfulPercent: to upgrade the full 20 levels
votesHelpful: you'll need hundreds of material items. Which you cannot buy in bulk
votesTotal: you have to laboriously dismantle equipment
votesFunny: one at a time. And you'll never find enough of certain materials
commentsCount: and you can't afford to buy them
column16: because by the time you have enough money
column17: you can't find the low-level stuff to buy any more
column18: even though it yields exactly the same "1 material" as the much more expensive stuff. Useless.\n\nAlchemy? Not bad
column19: but really not useful. That is
column20: even if you can find the ingredients in your pack once you have them. Sadly
column21: there doesn't seem to be any order or reason to how they throw it into the pack. So you spend most of your time mousing over to see what it was you wanted to put together. Even then
column22: alchemy really isn't that useful in the game.\n\nFight mechanics are a wash. Initially you can't do anything
column23: and you'll end up dying a lot.  At least TW1 gave you an option of dodging a lot when facing tough opponents. TW2 - nope

And if you time it you can sprint out of the way of a blow by the larger creatures. The fighting system still sucks though.\n\nThen there's the horses. In TW1 they were bad enough

reviewText: Two World II is a RPG/Action Game. Set in the Medievil times around 1400-1600. The Singleplayer i have yet to try even though i have played around 24 hours on it so far. The Mutiplayer is very entartaining, with 8 Mission + 4 DLC Missions. There is a lot of different classes and races you can play, such as A Elf Warrior, A Dwarf Fire Mage, A Human Necromancer, Dark Elf Ranger, Orc Two Handed Weapon Warrior... And your characters customtion is good with a lot of different styles. There are 5 Different Gamemode with 1 DLC gamemode, the gamemodes are good, with Adventure ( The Missions), Duel ( PVP) Crystal Capture, Team Deathmatch and the DLC Gamemode is Defence. You have a leveling system in the game, I'm Currently Level 42 on my main account and 36 on my second. There is also a village mode on mutiplayer, you pay 10,000 Auras ( Game Money) to build a village then you can build Ranchs, Farms, Windmills, Taverns...etc. But you get money from this village like when you build a shop you get profit, but if you build something that requires a upkeep, then you lose profit, you get your profit ( Lets say i have 1000 Profit) every 6 mins ( in real time). Sometimes your village moral go's down causing you to lose profit, but you can kill the creatures, which increases your villages moral. This Game is really loads of fun and me and my friends spend a lot of time on it, either Leveling up ourself's or speed leveling are friends ( you will understand Speed leveling once you play this game). This game is worth Spending money on, maybe not the DLC as it is not worth the asking price, so i'm lucky i got the game and DLC off Tremor. My Rating 10/10 :D

reviewText:
So my first impressions of this game are pretty good so far. It's a vast improvement over the 1st in both gameplay and acting but even then the combat is fairly easy to grasp but tricky to to actually do when fighting more than one enemy. It's been set in a beautiful world however filled with different types of enemies and some side quests to keep you entertained should you decide to do them. I enjoy watching the clips which are well animated and sword fight early on in the game between an Orc and armour clad Knight was pretty entertaining to watch thanks to the way it was animated.

VOICE ACTING

The voice acting is good in some places and not so good in others with the main character neither being the best or worst of the lot but in the long run he talks in a grumpy whisper ALL the time with little or no emotion shown in his lines and, truth be told, listening to him speak caused me to turn on subtitles and skip the dialogue.

Which leads me to my next issue. The Subtitles are poorly written, whether or not this was done in some kind of translation or just by sheer lack of proofreading what is actually said is sometimes a little different to whats written. This wouldn't be a problem if not for the grammer and placement issues I noticed so even though the actors make perfect sense the subtitles sometimes don't.

GAME WORLD

RPG's like this need a strong world to back it up, one that looks good and encourages me to explore and yes it is absolutely beautiful and the enemies in it are often well animated and nice to look at (all except the Groms which annoy me) but I felt no drive to go exploring too far off the road for fear of the extremely tough enemies that randomly plague the wilderness. This game has no leveled zones and, unlike Skyrim on consoles, the world does not level with you. At level 2 you could fight something very capable fo turning you into mince in less than ten seconds so choose your battles wisely. The first town you start in is located in the Sahvanna which is nice and has some enemies often not seen in RPG's like Baboons, Rhinos and other such enemies.

COMBAT

Combat is easy to pick up. You learn it step by step in the tutorial sections so if you cant block from the get go, worry not because you still need to learn how. Melee comes first then Archery and finally Magic which people (including me) say is a strong point in the game thanks to the customizable spells. Archery and Magic are all auto aim but Melee is a different story, You need to think tactically to some degree though most enemies are a hack and slash affair.

What surprised me was the stealth system of the game. You can sneak up behind enemies and stab them in the back with a pretty simplistic animation but this only works on humanoids so far as I know. Though I did notice a fair amount of enemies seem to be have their backs turned in the worst places such as beside a cliff. Why would you be staring into a wall of rock when your back is so exposed to an assisination from behind. It's alnost like they invite you to get that free kill!

SKILLS

So there's a variety of crafting skills from alchemy to blacksmithing which work but its really hard to explain their function. Lockpicking in this game is quite simple but rewarding and the minigame used to pick the locks is both easy but clever.

MUSIC

This game has a really good soundtrack. The ambience to the scores during cutscenes are great in my opinion and really bring something good to this beautiful world filled with boring people. You can even buy an intrument and some song sheets though I never got to see if you could play them or not as I wasn't wasting money on it.

As I play through the game I plan on adding more to my review.

reviewText:
While alot of the things in this game disappoint me, I have to say that this is the best magic system I have ever came across in any game, ever. (Seriously, buy this game, but only when it's 80% off.)
But this cannot override how crappy almost everything else in the game is.

1. Let's start with animations:
My character's running looks like a japanese schoolgirl running towards senpai (the kneecaps face inwards when running), his attack movements (especially spellcasting) are just off. The horses I guess are okay, but a little clunky in movement.

2. Menus and stuff:
While the developers have tried to add a sense of fantasy into the menues, gold and blue don't go well together, especailly in this game. Their dragon thing surrounding the health bar looks extravagent. They should try a more minimalistic design.

3. Quests:
While the quest system is fine, the objectives and how you get there is often confusing and hard to navigate. Also there's nobody you can ask for clues, or even to repeat the quest dialougue. However, in some situations the quest navagation system is too straightforward, and I literally skipped through half the plot and beat the boss without really knowing the Story while I spent the other half of my time trying to scale mountains and get to the destination before realizing there was a shortcut that can only be opened after completing the quest there. While this might sound intruiging, I assure you it is not after 3 hours of rigorous scaling.

4. Difficulty spikes:
I don't know if this is just me, but there have been huge difficulty level changes ever since the start. The game expects you to grind, and if you don't, you can't progress. When I was in the swamp navigating my way through undeads, it took me ten minutes to kill 7 of them, and that was using summons and heals all the way through. While about ten minutes before, I was tearing through monsters in the last chapter easily. While this may sound like a personal complaint, I think TW2 should at least offer you a decent difficulty slope from chapter to chapter.

5. FInal boss:
I spent the entire game building weird magic spells that held so much potential they could be viewed as cheats, and the final boss turns out to be an FPS.

6. Voice acting:
Don't turn on the sound, just don't

Overall, although I rated it down, this game is worth getting (ONLY ON SALES WHERE THEY ARE 80% OFF)
The innovative magic system alone makes this game worth at least a few hours. But fair warning, don't expect much out of the game other than the supercool magic system.

reviewText:
An incredible magic and item management system, a beautiful, open world, and a roster of interesting characters that inspire empathy are marred to unplayability by bugs, broken DRM, extremely unbalanced mechanics, bad voice acting for the main character and about a third of the interactions, and a blase storyline.

Pros:

--The magic and inventory management is hands-down the best I've seen in an RPG in decades. This alone has kept me investing my hours in this game. Do-it-yourself spells and every item in the game upgradeable and able to be dismantled into the components needed to upgrade anything makes character building a treat.

--Though the character models and textures look like something from 2003, the post-processing is very good, and the world is vast and full of surprises.

--Between dice, grinding, pickpocketing, vendors that buy and sell at different prices, and a DDR-like musical minigame, there's plenty of ways to make money.

--horses, boats, and fast travel - you can get to where you need to go quickly. It's almost too easy...

Cons:

--extra DRM! The Steam release of TW2 did not have the original CD DRM stripped, and the activation server is almost constantly down or unreachable. You will have to call a German number and manually activate it, or find the developer forum and email the head developer to have him manually activate it. This game came out in 2011, not 2001 - this is outright unacceptable, and if not for Steam's no-refunds policy, I would be screaming for a refund. (Glares menacingly at Ubisoft and EA for the same sin)

--Yo Dawg, I heard you like DRM... Used one of the patches before the end of Chapter 1? Uh-oh, you have to re-activate at the end of Chapter 1!

--But not in the GoG.com version. Seriously.

--Bugs. Do not upgrade before Chapter 2, every patch breaks locked doors that require using cheats to unlock in Chapter 1. Some quests get bugged horribly, and some vendors never open up after dawn ever again. Save often, you never know what will screw up. Getting bugged through walls and off cliff edges, items skyrocketing because collision detection went insane, items that don't deposit into inventory correctly...ugh.

--Butt-ugly inventory management system. It really is one of the most innovative ever, but damn is it ugly. can't move anything in stacks, have to click an are you sure" dialogue

reviewText:
This game is one of my favorite games. It has so much free roam and the story was great. Every time I play this game I have so much fun. There are some minor problems, but critics tore it apart for these issues. I must say it was very unfair too, as these issues were not game breaking and the critics completely ignored a great game because of them.

Cons
-Everything above the mouth on your characters looks lifeless. In other words, your eyes and nose don't move (but your hair does).
-The money system is a little messed up. (The best way to make money is by the Guitar Hero" mini game.)
-Changed the outcome from the ending of the first game.
-The voice actor for the hero is a little bit off. (I liked his deeper voice
date:
but I can understand why some may not).
-The ending is a little frustrating

Really that's about it
recommended: yet critics would fixate on one minor issue and act like it was something big. That's why this game has become a hidden gem.\n\nThis game has so much going for it. There are loads of side quests on top of an already decent sized main line. The environment graphics are great! It looks good in all places
hoursPlayed:
especially for 2011. There is lots of free roam and mechanics that you will want to explore.

Pro
-The alchemy system is fantastic
-The "Guitar Hero" mini game is fun and addictive
-The story is quite interesting
-Lots of dungeons to explore (including a set of 10 dungeons that you can't use your map in and the entire thing is completely dark)
-Great level system once again
-Awesome magic system that has some real fun depth. (Look at some Youtube videos to see what I mean)
-The whole game feels so original.
-ONE OF THE BEST SOUNDTRACKS IN A GAME

This is such a great game. I have finished it about 8 times on console. Sure there is not Skyrim free roam capability

reviewText: It's a great game. I really, honestly do love it. It is an open world RPG in the third person. You face many enemies. One of my favorite (and, a lot of the time the thing I hate most of the game) is how you start getting behind in levels to your enemies. They do not level up with you - they stay the same level. This requires you to either face VERY challenging enemies or do side quests a LOT to keep up. The thing I could say I dislike about the game is the combat system. It's fun at first, but it gets old fast. It is also very glitchy. However, it's an overall great game with my certain recommendation!

reviewText: It's not a badly made game, if you can brave the Trial of 1000 DRMs
date:
that is.

Forget the fact that players bought the game on Steam, which is itself a form of DRM. Forget the fact that players have the keys on the Steam overlay and that copy+paste has been a thing for decades. The game makes every new player manually enter four serial numbers and fill out a form with all their personal information before it lets them play.

Seriously, no game is worth the hassle, and no game devloper is entitled to that information. Play Mass Effect instead.

reviewText:
Enemies are often only defeatable if you glitch them through ANY doorway.  Combat is clunky, uncontrollable, and awkward.  Magic customization is cool, but doesn't matter when 90% of the time you must glitch enemies through terrain to even be able to hit them.

In case you were wondering, yes I am that serious.  I rarely write reviews for games, but the combat, pathfinding, bugs, and general gameplay on this game are so attrocious that I would hate for anyone else to purchase it.

I really remember two worlds 1 being much much better than this is.  Not that it was great but I found it moderately enjoyable.  The enemies and quests are so bug-ridden in this game that it is not.  In this game enemies often stop moving completely just to be repeatedly shot by arrows.

Believe me, I enjoy a good B-rated game.  But not this, it isn't nearly as fun as tw1 and even that wasn't that great.

reviewText: i love this game. i played it all the way through on my ps3 and i'm about halfway through another playthrough with this version. the combat is fairly in depth for what admittedly feels like an unfinished. i'm not complaining in any way-this game's only real downside in my opinion is that there's not much info in-game as to spell crafting or potion making. but that can all be found online. i read some reviews on the store page before i decided to write mine and i noticed several people complaining about the drm. yes-there is one. yes you have to put in a serial number and yes they want a bunch of personal information-but if you're dumb enough to give that up, then you have only yourself to blame. i myself registered this game without any problems and filled in all the blanks with lies. unless you think my first name is really Rabbit and i live on 1234 boner st.\nseriously though, don't miss out on this great game because of some stupid drm. the graphics aren't perfect, and sometimes the lips don't sync up when they talk, but all in all, this game has dozens of hours of gameplay in single player, and almost as many in the multiplayer campaign (which can be played solo all the way through, but only if you're a badass hahaha)

reviewText:
First impressions:

Two Worlds 2 is an RPG, similar to Gothic, Elder Scrolls and Risen. It stands out for it’s kick-♥♥♥ magic spell system. They’ve come up with this do-it-yourself magic spell card engine which let’s you build custom spells. It’s fun and original, first time I gave the wizard-character a try in an RPG.

The game did a lot of things right and overall left a user-friendly and positive impression.

Pros:

+ Ok graphics
+ Cool character, kinda reminds me of Danny Trejo. Also, he has those small comments upon interaction which sound smart and help improve his personality.
+ Super fast loading time.
+ Ability to save custom outfits in case you need to quickly change from wizard to warrior etc. This should be a genre standard.
+ Mobile teleport platforms was a very good idea.
+ User-friendly mission guide that gives you good overview of where you have to go and what you have to do.
+ Huge variety of enemies throughout the game.

Unfortunately there were those tiny mistakes that could and should have been fixed and improved before the game came out. Those were mainly issues that made the game feel a little immature and green, as if the development team consisted of professionals and amateurs and everyone got to contribute.

Cons:

- I never got the idea behind the name ‘two worlds’. Was it supposed to be something metaphorical? I played as a wizard who looked a lot like Gandalf in his younger years and the events were taking place in a savanna/jungle so more than ‘two worlds’ the game felt like Gandalf’s Safari Adventures.

- Major flaw: the game crashed left and right. I could count as much as 5 crashes in 2 minutes. Then again that truly helped me appreciate the quick loading times.

- Character design was way over the top. All those ridiculous, skimpy armors and gosh, those shoulder plates!

- The Voice Acting ...this was such a major one. When you take a person with a normal voice and tell him to imitate a funny sounding person, then it sounds like a normal person is making funny sounds. That happened throughout the game. Voice acting in this game might be the worst I’ve ever experienced.

- The script/ writing. The dialogues were long and dead boring, the story was unnecessarily complicated + there were completely obsolete characters. It all comes down to really bad game script.

- Something that’s easily forgettable once you’re in-game, but how they implemented Digital Rights Management in this game was not acceptable. The kind of information they asked before I could play the game made me feel very reluctant and extremely uncomfortable.

- NPC movement speed compared to animation was out of place.

- The great paradox of Two Worlds 2 is the ability to outrun rhinos and panthers even though your stamina is depleted after 100 meters of sprinting.

- Swift moving around in combat makes the enemy AI go crazy, they will get stuck behind obstacles and go into attack mode some 5-6 meters from you.

- Banal, unrealistic female characters - a demoness, a vixen and a damsel in distress.

- Battles boil down to how fast you can click the mouse button.

Verdict:
The Cons list became quite long but let yourself not be discouraged by that, those were just minor flaws, all except the DRM issue which kills the gaming world and violates human rights. Overall it was a very positive experience and introduced many new original elements that I'd like to see become a genre standard.

reviewText:
I think this game could be fun but it isn’t that intriguing so its hard to get in to. So if you have anything else to play, you are going to ask yourself why you should play this one. It does not give you a reason early enough. I will out myself that I put in two hours and like 10mins was character creation. The short rating is that the game has stale dialogue, clunky combat, uninteresting characters, and little motivation to push through the tutorial.

Cons
- The dialogue is cheesy... but not in a fun cheesy way but like in an I am dark and isolated but not really" sort of way
- The controls were not really made for the PC. The controls are clunky and stupid... just saying
- The game isn’t optimized well… had random needless unexplained stuttering in empty dungeons.
- Needless running in empty hallways in between cinemas. Just play the full cinema instead of having me come in and out for no reason. You literally watch a cinema then walk through an empty room and have another cinema… this is not an exaggeration.
- The character creation seemed extremely limited. Basically 10 different choices in each category (plus sliders). So I suppose if you spend a lot of time you can make a very customized character… but I didn’t see any of the features I look for. For example
date:
facial hair options are basically all the same (i.e. short goatee ish beard). Hair options are basically the same length with slightly different styles… very slightly. No facial paint/tattoos. I know I started with I spent 10 minutes on character creation… but honestly it was less than that.
- Not sure if this is a fair con or not so I add it only to mention it but the story appears to be heavily dependent on the first game… so a lot is not explained.

Pros
- Sexy Orc woman who finally helps you understand D&D Half-Orcs
- A craft system exist… so that’s good
- Variety of combat style (typical though: magic
hoursPlayed:
melee).
- Interesting lock-picking system
- Magic system based on cards.
- Not really a pro but another worth mentioned… all the women I encountered so far are scantily dressed women who hold their own… so there is that

I wish I could recommend this game because there seems to be so much potential but that game felt more like a chore than a game… yes first world problems.
"

reviewText:
Two Worlds 2, everytime I come back to it it somehow can impress me all over again, from all the RPG mechanics to the amazing looking vistas. This is a truely wonderful RPG experience.

The first time I played it which was a few years ago, I was but a meer console baby, and as soon as I played fifteen minutes I dropped the game. What a terrible choice, a few years later I decide to pick it up again and I was blown away how much sheer diversity there is in the playing styles to all the armor and loot choices. The game really does make you feel like an adventuer, from exploring crumbling caverns to a long harsh Savannah Desert to deep forests.

The combat is a mixed review on my part, I feel as though they could have included a better control system even with a controller. Left trigger is sprint, left trigger is sneak and left trigger is draw. A bit silly due to all the playing styles they really had to fit alot of things in, the combat on the other hand features between an arrowing slinger Archer to a brave Warrior or just a spellslinging Mage. Even though the melee and ranged combat is pretty flawed, it really makes up for it in the spells. The ability to craft different combinations with three different enchantments, from a massive vortex to a chilling icebolt.

Over all, this game has really grown on me as a RPG - I suggest this to anyone who is looking for a good RPG.

reviewText: I had bought this game some time ago on disk (now unplayable due to computer/Windows progression) so when the game come as a download in Steam I decided to buy it. I previously finished the Pirates of the Flying Fortress many years ago but hadn't finished Two Worlds and wanted to finish it. To my surprise it didn't live up to my expectations. The Function keys were difficult to remember like F7 for map when I am used to M on other games but I dealt with that ok. I remembered how the game went in the past and things were coming back to me on how to play it. What stopped me from continuing to play was the fact that the game crashed too often. What I mean is that I would be questing, then I wanted to bring up my map to look at my location and instead the game wouuld put me on the desktop. This happened too often and so I tried to deal with it by saving frequently but it got annoying. I would not recommend this game because of this fact. It wasn't just the map function, it happened on other functions like bringing up my skills, etc. Strange, I don't remember this problem when I played the game in the past from the disk.

reviewText:
Positive
+ In terms of graphics, this ends up being a positive mark for the game. While character models and animations leave much to be desired, some of the environments (and the textures themselves) are really well-detailed, including ancient Asian and Egyptian architecture, as well as some impressive lighting that is determined to showcase the best the graphics have to offer
+ Taking around 10 ½ hours to complete the main story (on Medium difficulty) is a good length in and of itself. But, if you really want to explore everything the game has to offer, you can easily net yourself another 20-30 hours of gametime. There’s no shortage of side-quests to complete
+ There’s an abundance of different (though basic) gameplay mechanics; from upgrading weapons via blacksmithing, to alchemy, lock picking (surprisingly one of the most fun lock picking minigames I’ve played), and even some stealth mechanics thrown in to offer some variety. And, while the combat is relatively simple, there’s a good variation of skills to use (including ones for melee and ranged weapons, as well as spells) that prevent the combat from being too repetitive or bland, and allows you to tweak your character to fit your preferred playstyle.


Negative
- Easily the biggest negative for me is the lack of difficulty scaling. What this basically means is: if you want to play the game just for the main story, you will have an exceedingly difficult time doing so (even on Medium difficulty). The game will force you to resort to cheap tactics in order to beat boss battles/hard encounters and run past most of the enemies throughout the dungeons, unless you complete side-quests (which there are plenty of, but I don’t think it’s fair to force the player to complete them in order to have a fair chance of defeating the main obstacles the game throws at you). This ends up making the game artificially difficult, as no matter how well you utilise or level your skills, you will have a needlessly problematic trek towards the end credits if you don’t complete optional content (unfortunately the final boss itself is rather awful as well, so I wouldn’t blame you if you felt like quitting before reaching the end)
- While there are plenty of side-quests to complete, the world itself--which may be big in scale--doesn’t really encourage exploration. There are simply vast masses of land that don’t contain any meaningful sights nor secrets worth discovering, which is a shame because the world itself is quite pretty
- Again, like the first game, the wooden voice acting and weak sound design in general don’t make much of an attempt to immerse you into the world of Antaloor; though I will admit, the music itself is very charming and partially redeems the sound overall
- Lastly, the story itself is predictable and forgettable; no interesting main characters and nothing that hasn’t been done before.


Worth Mentioning
• Though people claim the game has severe DRM, all it really is is putting in a serial number, and using online activation to verify your purchase (which only needs to be done once). It literally takes only 30 seconds to do so... unless you forget to uncheck the checkbox which tells you to register (which makes you enter personal details, but this isn’t required to play the game at all). But, if you hate ‘DRM’ in any form (excluding Steam DRM), then by all means don’t bother purchasing the game.


Verdict
“Two Worlds II starts off as a rather clunky experience. But, once you start getting into the swing of things, you will find yourself enjoying the game more and more as you delve deeper into it. While the game is just a basic open-world RPG, with both poor and good qualities mixed together, overall this and the first game have an undeniable charm that makes them memorable (and admittedly better than they deserve to be). With some more polish here and there, this game could be even better than I’m giving it credit for.”

7/10 TJBs

reviewText: With its huge open world, interesting combat system and tons of main and side quests, this game is a big recommendation. It's similar to Skyrim in some segments but it kept it's own spirit and interesting story. With expansion pack you're in it for more than a hundred hours of content. Not to mention amazing graphics considering this was not a project as big or expensive as Skyrim. Music is also very pleasant and it ads to the atmosphere. I want that soundtrack in CD quality.\nSo, all in all, if you can buy this game, buy it. If you like old school RPGs, buy it. If you're not some lazy, spoiled kid, used to have everything pinpointed to you like in today's World of Warcfraft, buy it.

reviewText:
Dont buy it on steam, it comes with DRM that limits you to three activations, supposedly you can recover the activations if you uninstall the game first.  The problem is that they will evaporate for any minor upgrade to your PC and who the hell can remember every 5 dollar game that needs an uninstall before you add a new hard drive.  You can get ths game on GOG where it should be DRM free just wait for a sale.  I understand also you can get new activations by contacting the developer but see it as a trial no one needs.  Currently my version is asking me to reactivate because I made a hardware change so it knows I havent done a reinstall but for some minor hardware update that I cant rememeber making aside from the fan I added I have used one of my activations.


Do your self a favor and buy this on GOG or wait tell the developer removes the DRM on steam, I personaly wont throw the developer more money for the same game and will leave my copy unactivated untill I actually intend to play it through .



Just a side note I have learned that even the GOG version has DRM but it is for the multiplayer part only,  the single player part of the game on GOG is DRM free.

reviewText:
Gameplay is smooth, combat is simple when you get used to it, the controls don't feel clunky like Gothic 4 ( where you can spam pick-up and the character does 20 squats before picking up the item and where hitting enemies is a chore ).

The game has plenty of side-quests, twists, and more. The price I paid wouldn't have even gotten me a movie ticket, or a popcorn at the movies, at that was with buying it 3 times; For a game from 2011, it definitely plays quite well.

If you think the price of a few coffees, a movie ticket, or a few soft-drinks is worth it, consider the cost to entertainment value for a game like this and buy it. If you're on the fence about the $20 price-tag, wait until it is on sale ( the bundle sites still have it too at a steal ) but at $10, it is more than worth it.

reviewText:
Keep in mind i have less than an hour on this game.
With that being said, lets take a look into what i think of this game.

1st. The tutorial feels too long- after what feels like a step by step guide to how to play, on a basic scale.  I feel tired of the  game already, from learning to running, jumping, how to sneak, attacking, blocking, finally after learning it all over with different weapons. keep in mind, you're learning how to do all this in a span of an hour. Its not entertaining at all, when they could throw in a press LMB to Attack followed & RMB to block.  Rather than there method of doing a full two cutscenes and a one on one battle to learn just that move.  If that's the case make a training room or tutorial button in the menu that ran you through it.  Not try to blend it in with the story.

2nd. The main character- Now this is my biggest problem, it kills the game for me, i can deal with a long tutorial but this will stick with me the whole game.  Its sad to say, but i hate how the main character sounds, like a bad guy in some old time bad film trying to like he is a terribly drawn out hero. making it  hard to follow a story that can not be take serious, its all like some big silly joke, that i did not find funny apparently.  With that said i want to touch on the character creation screen.  you get what, 5 options?  how large of shoulders, chest, and leg length.  what is the point of having a creaton screen when its really how tall you want your guy?  There is no female option since it would bother the story line, you can't change the descent enough hair style.

3rd. The combat- the very little that i player i did encounted some bad guys so to speak, and i had to fight them.  Nothing more to say than the fact i feel as if later through the game, ill be clicking, a lot.  Im sure it will get harder later on but for now im saying the combat is really badly done.  I tend to notice very little use of the movement keys during it since it makes you go crazy and turn your back on the locked on enemy. very big flaw i'd say.

4th. Character animation- At points you can clearly see the mouths not matching the words spoken. Some movements feel as if im watching a kids show.  the movement looks really silly in cutscenes at times.  I could ramble on about a few other flaws but its not drastic enough to mention. So moving on,

lastly what i find actually amusing about the game.

1st.  The scenery- now i am a big fan of dragons, though there is maybe too much dragons placed every where.  I can't say i hate it.  Then once you actually get outside you can see a beautiful landscape, with plenty of vegitation.  Even the intro clip has an clever way of showing it.  No doubt they captured my eye showing the orc, i guess, fleet docking on the shores to charge the castle.  So a plus on that,

2nd. Credit- In the short time of me playing this game i was able to find more bad about it than good.  Other that have many more hours than me could say other wise.  I do give them credit though its not a terrible game. Its not unplayable and im sure it evens out in bad and good later on.  though I may not ever see the ending of this potentionally good game.  Don't let my opinion stop you, im not saying the game is trash, or so bad that it makes me cry.  I rather not be treated like a kid growing up, and get straight into the action.  If you feel the same, i would say wait for a sale.  If you do not agree with me, feel free to go on ahead and purchase this game.  I just hope you get back what you paid for from it.

*Also this is the first review that i actually took time and sat down and really said a lot about a game.  I appologise for anyone that disagrees and feels offended.  As well to those notice the many grammer mistakes, take note that i am writting this at 6:17 am in the morning from staying up all night.  thank you *

reviewText:
This game requires contact details such as address, name, gender and phone number to activate and register.
The cutscenes and dialogue are cheesier than a dairy farm, occasionally break (character capes flipping over their head and projecting through their chest), and there is god-awful writing throughout with bizarre sexist jokes that make little sense in context or from the characters that speak them.

The customisation of your character at the start of the game allows intense modifications of the facial features you will never see through the back of your head and not much else at ALL. The early combat is about as fun and intuitive as putting a wet towel over your face and swinging a stick blindly hoping you spam the right attack to win. The keyboard controls are awful but controlling your character with a gamepad is difficult as well.

And apparently the multiplayer is dead anyway.

Do not buy this game.

reviewText:
Horrible RPG, horrible game. Tries to skim off of the Elder Scrolls games, but fails miserably. Clunky combat, forgettable story and laughable dialogue. Nothing stands out but the extreme blandness of the world and its characters.

Worst of all, Two Worlds II has the CRAPPIEST RPG UI I'VE EVER USED - it's simply unmanageable. Too many key commands, too many mouse clicks and not enough quick ways to access inventory, spells, and whatever else. In a way, it's like trying to sort through one's .cfg collection using Windows 95's decrepit file-folder system. Does that sound like fun to you? Hell no it doesn't.

Avoid TWII like the shovelware it is. If you really need a cheaper Skyrim fix, buy Divinity II. It's a much, much better game.

reviewText:
Right after the opening cutscene, the game requested CD Keys and my data.

You already use Steam for DRM, why the hell do you want to do this? Let the players play the game, and don't treat your legit customers like thieves.

Definitely not a good idea. Seems that most recent TopWare games do this (X-Blades for example).

Uninstalled. I haven't touched the game. The hours I've logged in was from idling for the cards.

And judging by the reviews it's not that really a great game.

Refer to CDProjektRED/GOG on how to do business.

Glad I got it for free.

reviewText:
A couple of things that makes this, otherwise perfectly functional game, a drab, slow and messy experience:

1. The controls. They are aweful in general. No matter how much you fine-tune it, it always feels bulky and there is no good way to swap between weapons.

2. The inventory screens are hap-hazard at best, something that was probably nailed pre-alpha and just never got a make-over because the developers had gotten used to it. Think of it like this: it's worse thank Skyrim but slightly better than Witcher is what we're talking about.

3. There is some pretty in-depth character creation but you can only be a male character for whatever plot reason.

If you can live with those things, sure, get it's. It's a good game otherwise. I just find that the combat breaks immersion too much by being ♥♥♥♥.

reviewText:
I am genuinely writing this review purely on the based that I already know Two Worlds 2 is a bad RPG from an even worse prequel. So I decided to buy the game and try it out and sure enough, I am greeted with one of the worst intro to games Ive ever seen on Steam.

First, you log on and it asks you to enter the 16 digit serial key. Bare in mind, I've NEVER had to do this on Steam. Never. Steam always provides it, but it doesn't seem to come up.

Second, after you put in this code which, really wasnt that big of a deal, now you have to activate your account? Wait what? Is this an MMORPG all of a sudden? You have to put in your name, address, state, DOB, e-mail. Just to play a Single player game. I'm surprised I dont have to put in a Credit Card number too with some screen telling me that Note: Your card will not be charged! This is just to have you on file!"

Third
date: ITS A BAD GAME.\n\nDon't waste your time with this aggressive nitpicky activation garbage just to play a bad RPG that shouldnt even exist."

reviewText:
YES! I most certainly recommend this game!!
there is so much to do in this game, so much to explore that would defo create a very unique gameplay.
I started to like action RPGs after playing Elder Scrolls Skyrim, and as I finished the game I was looking for something similar, and well.. I found this game.
I was not very sure about this game, it starts very bland but put a few hours to it and you would love it.
the cities are bigger than the Skyrim's towns, its a free-to-explore, open world RPG and its massive!
the story is very good and the game is addictive, a true solid RPG.
there are a few problems though, some dialogues with NPCs are a little bland, the horse riding is stupid and the menus are a tad confusing.
dont get me wrong, after a few hours you would start to enjoy it and it can be a good replacement for elder scrolls series.
combat is very good and fun, magic is awesome, crafting and forging is very good and you have all the cool stuff like alchemy, enchanting (sort of!), upgarding weapons and customizing your character.
there are guilds to join, and tons of quests to do.
dungeons, demons, undead creatures, necromancers, everything you would want from a RPG.
take my advice and buy it, you will love it as much as I do!

oh, and i almost forgot; this game has a true FULL CONTROLLER SUPPORT!!

reviewText:
This game is Quite good. Not great, but not bad.

Positives:
-Great magic system (I mean REALLY GREAT. like to make your own things in rgps? Now you can create spells!)
-Easy to run on older computers.
-Fun to play with others.
-Good storyline (except the start. I was clueless on what was going on)

Negatives:
-Melee combat still sucks (spam click untill everything in front of you is dead)
-Singleplayer is not level-based, so even at level 1 there will be really hard enemys.
-Multiplayer is not barren, but most servers (towns) are empty.
-Singleplayer gameplay is quite slow, and before you can use everything, you must go through this large prologue (Which also acts as a tutorial)

I would rate this game a 7.5/10

reviewText:
This game is so frustrating and pointless when it starts, but when u reach Hatmandor, its totally a different, that is when the real game starts.As for the game mechanics, the magic is creative- you can experiment with spells,tons of variety in items.Beautiful ambience,various types of enemies

The only downsides are that
-Weird interface and inventory system, but you get used to that.
-For some, the horse riding may seem irritating(the horse riding is realistic-that is how horse riding should be in a game)
-Controls are weird,kinda unresponsive (XBOX 360 controller recommended)

Despite of the above flaws, I find it easy to lose myself in this game. I'm sure this game isn't for everyone, but if you love a good fantasy RPG I doubt you will be disappointed by Two Worlds II.
