reviewText: This game is literally awesome.  Great graphics, great open world, great store, great quests - especially the side quests.  I have been thoroughly amazed by the writing and the dialogue.  The voice acting is stellar, the main character sounds like Christian Bale's Batman.  A healthy amount of coarse language, not overdone - just appropriate.  I guess my only complaint is that like the Gothic series the combat is leveled for the most part meaning once you plateau past a certain level enemies become a joke to deal with.  Sooner rather than later since you level so quickly and gain so many skills and stat boosts there isnt much of a challenge.\n\nI suggest anyone who likes the Gothic/Risen series give this game a try - its a much more polished, entertaining, coherent game that will last with you long after the game is done.

reviewText: This game is a mixed bag to tell the truth. Massive amount of content which promise hours and hours of gameplay, that is if one is willing to overlook its flaws which make the game a chore to trudge through. Customization is fair although the single player campaign isn't as lenient and exciting as the multiplayer character customization. Combat is clunky at best and weapons dont have any weight to them, although the magic system makes up for it that is if the player is willing to be a mage above all else. There are a variety of enemies to fight against which makes combat refreshing despite the controls and horrid physics. Character models look stiff and unfinished although at times they look great (in cutscenes), maybe its the fact that the arms look really weird and unfinished. Voice acting is bearable most of the time although your character can get annoying at times. Action is pretty much average to say the most, story is decent, Two Worlds II isn't exactly going to be everyone's cup of tea but its a decent game in its own right. 6/10.

reviewText:
After hearing how horrible this was in all the years since its release, I have to say that I was pleasantly surprised by this game. The voice acting is terrible, the combat is weird at times, and the context sensitive keys seem like a useless relic from console porting, but this game feels like the first Witcher, but without timed button press combat. so far much of what I have been doing is following a tiny main quest thread and running around killing monsters for people.

I'm a total sucker for games with a crafting system, and even though this one is kind of bare bones(only item improvements; no actual item creation) it is still fairly rewarding. Another huge bonus somewhat related to this is that your armor actually changes when you equip new pieces. It isn't just 8 reskinned versions of the same armor ala Dragon Age: Origins. Every set so far feels like a unique and interesting enough looking piece of armor. Cloaks abound, with decent cloth physics, though I have seen one scene where the cloak was draped across a character's body the wrong way, clipping through his chest and draping over his front.

I'm playing this game with the Worldmerge mod, since I have the DLC and it is reportedly more immersive this way. The game looks amazing with DX10. Whenever I launch it with DX9 it just looks fuzzy in comparison. There is a huge amount of realistic plantlife dotting the landscape. It makes grassy fields in skyrim look like child's play.

After putting it off for such a long time, I feel absolutely blown away by this game.

Edit: the ending is a little confusing and kind of a let down. Just...be prepared for nearly nothing to be explained.

reviewText: The best open world Fantasy RPG since Morrowind, and one of my favorite games of all-time. The amount of content in it is pretty unbelievable.  The only reason I stopped playing the singleplayer was because I beat the game and literally killed every single monster in the game's world. I still periodically load it up to play the guitar mini-game. Playing through the separate coop mode was a great bonus on top of an already immense game.  A++, would exterminate the baboon population of Antaloor again.

reviewText: I like the magic system in this game better than the one in Skyrim . You can preset five different spells, and switch between them without stopping the action . You need a staff to use magic, but you can also use the staff defensively to hit your opponents . You make your own spells by organizing what looks like Tarot cards into amulets .... The armor looks better, after you spend some money, but the archer's clothing still looks like something Uncle Joe wouls buy at the local sporting goods store .... There's a bit of humor in the game, and plenty of dungeons .... The inventory system can be confusing at first, because of the (quick switch) system that allows you to change between mage, archer, and fighter instantly .... A spell and a puff of smoke for that (quick switch) would make it more believable .... For some reason, the thieves guild gives you the best prices on any gear .... Don't upgrade weapons and armor too much at first, because the stuff you collect as the game progresses is much much better ....The music is highly atmospheric .... Those stiff hand jesticulations that characters make when talking remind me of cheap old kung fu movies Ha Ha .

reviewText:
Positives:

It has a nice world. The world itself looks pretty good, and it's cool to roam around.
The character customization is pretty alright.

End of list.

Negatives:

The controls are really confusing, especially to a beginner. There's way too many for the player's own good.
Quite a buggy game. During in-game cutscenes if you're next to an object it'll sometimes fly like being hit with a giant hammer or you'll phase into it.
Fights are boring. There's barely any sound or music when you fight, and it doesn't feel like you're actually fighting like in other RPG's.
Voice acting isn't very good. No music during cutscenes.

End of list.

4/10 do not recommend.

reviewText:
My Review On Two Worlds II

This is the worst game ever, I have spent god knows how long trying to play this game.

First things first, I went to play this game since I liked the first one and saw thiswas cheap so I bought it, however after successfully installing and downloading it, it wouldn't run, after launch it would just not open a window or anything, so I looked on the forum and it said try restarting steam so I did that, it didn't work, it also said try restarting your computer, so I did that, didn't work, twenty minutes after it started to work, then it asked me for all this stpid information after I just bought the game asking me to buy even more things just so taht I can play it, and it would seem that apparently I PAID to play the stupid demo of a game that is years old. Second after filling in all this information and getting an email sent to me and buying a serial code, it said that my code was invalid, it said everything I tried was invalid, also everytime I want to launch the game, out of all my games it takes the longest to load and it is one of the smallest, then it makes me watch a stupid intro vid tat you can't skip. Out of all the games the story looks okay, but since I have only been able to play the demo since apparently I am an invalid player/owner of the game. Overall this is the worst game ever, and forcing  someone to fill in their personal details such as their exact location and proxy server should be illegal in which some cases it is, I will never download or play any game from these devs ever again, and I say this for all gamers, stop this miss conduct. The amount of glitches in game, is terrible.

I do not recommend anyone ever plays this, I want a refund!

reviewText:
After 32 hours of gameplay I'm still playing this game and I don't know why. The actual gameplay is fun, but it still has so many problems. I found one game-breaking bug that trapped me in a dungeon, but I was able to get out with console commands. I can no longer stand to hear any of the dialog; the voice acting and script are both so bad.

I also sailed to the largest island in the game, only to find out you can't go to it - if you happen to make it in it teleports you back to the shore. It takes a fair bit of time to get there, so don't waste your time trying. You can only go to the small islands on the map.

And because I spent some time exploring around before doing missions I'm an unstoppable death machine with no equal in combat - it's starting to make things a bit boring due to the lack of challenge.

-------------------------------------------------

ORIGINAL REVIEW:

I wish I could even play this game. It took a half hour of searching the internet for a way to get the game to even launch and when it did start working, it wasn't due to anything I did because I hadn't changed anything - merely tried to launch it a few more times and then it spontaneously worked (as far as I can tell). Then, once it was running, it kept crashing every few minutes. On top of all of that, they have the balls to put advertisements in the game to try to sell you other things. It also forced all control to my 360 controller I had plugged in without giving me an option to switch to mouse control, which somehow made registration impossible because I couldn't pick a gender.

Infuriating" is a rather kind description of my experience with this game so far. I'd like to play it
date: and I'm going to continue to try for a little while
recommended:
but after fighting to get it to work at all for this long I simply can't recommend it to anyone.

-------------------------------------------------

EDIT: Bandicam appears to have been what was causing it to crash. not sure why it wouldn't start up at first. The game is fun
hoursPlayed: but lips don't match dialog and characters move in cutscenes as if they were marionets. Dialog seems to jump around randomly between subjects sometimes and every now and then it just skips itself mid-sentence as if it expects you were bored."
voteText: February 19, 2014

reviewText:
I love this game, played it through completely at least twice.  Bought 2 copies, this one for my steam library.  Be aware that many of the negative reviews of this game are based solely upon the (quite legitimate) concerns about intrusive DRM, which we all kinda despise, especially as Steam users we aught not to be subjected to it.  That aside, once the monkey hoops are jumped through, this is an absolutely marvellous game.

+ The graphics are amazing and the environments are some of the most beautiful and best of any game I have played, in face I would say THE best.  The savannah is amazing, totally atmospheric, feels like a real savannah aught to, and the Japanese-style college of magick is also gorgeous.  Like something from a dream the designer had and they made it real.  It might be a little dated now, though, that was my impression playing this back few years ago.

+ The enemies are not level scaled, which I really like.  Some are very tough and cant be defeated at the start of the game, necessitating going back after your character has levelled a little.  I really like this mechanic, although some folks I know want every enemy to be beatable at any level, like in Bethesda games, which I always usually get bored of as partway through the game your character is more powerful than the game curve and every enemy is toast even on highest difficulty.  So thumbs up to Two Worlds for this, and I hope to see tough, non level-scaled enemies in Two Worlds 3 also.

There are lots of other great things in this game but these are the 2 that really stick in my mind.  Horses and boats are great also come to think of it.

Anyway this game should be getting 90%+ I think on recommendations, its being brought down by the DRM unfortunatley, but IMHO it's well worth jumping through the hoops to play this amazing game.

reviewText: Two Worlds II. What else should be said about it? The melee combat is fairly atrocious. The voice-overs are similarly terrible. But the one saving grace of this game is how broken the magic system is. Not only can you summon a legion of weird sea monstrosities, but you can summon anvils that fall out of the sky, turn yourself invisible, and walk on water. And that is why I play it. reviewText:
If you are looking to buy this game, please heed my warning.
Do not step into multiplayer, if you can't speak german. Multiplayer servers are riddled with german people, who won't speak english. They understand english, but they just wont speak it.

Now with that warning out of the way.
This game is very good. Graphics are pleasant and not that demanding. If you ever get bored of bashing groms and doglike humanoid creatures, go to a town sit at a table, throw some dice or play a violin ! (yea you can do that)

Magic system in this game are close to suppreme, I have spent many hours into this game mainly as a mage and I haven't even scratched the surface. You could make devastating spells that ricochet between enemies, everytime they ricoche they explode in 7 meter radius. Yeah that devastating.

Melee system could need some rework. There are alot of fun moves in this game wich you can utilize to banish those pesky Necris back into their graves or maybe you could bash that friendly shopkeeper down a cliff. Who knows ?

Archery is quite fun too, with the sniper mode you can mark several enemies to be shot with multi arrow. You can shoot elemental arrows fire, ice and poison. Distraction arrow is a fun mechanic, it summons a horrible creature at arrow location, who taunts your enemies.

There are alot of loot to find and many creatures to be slain.

reviewText:
I love this game, played it through completely at least twice.  Bought 2 copies, this one for my steam library.  Be aware that many of the negative reviews of this game are based solely upon the (quite legitimate) concerns about intrusive DRM, which we all kinda despise, especially as Steam users we aught not to be subjected to it.  That aside, once the monkey hoops are jumped through, this is an absolutely marvellous game.

+ The graphics are amazing and the environments are some of the most beautiful and best of any game I have played, in face I would say THE best.  The savannah is amazing, totally atmospheric, feels like a real savannah aught to, and the Japanese-style college of magick is also gorgeous.  Like something from a dream the designer had and they made it real.  It might be a little dated now, though, that was my impression playing this back few years ago.

+ The enemies are not level scaled, which I really like.  Some are very tough and cant be defeated at the start of the game, necessitating going back after your character has levelled a little.  I really like this mechanic, although some folks I know want every enemy to be beatable at any level, like in Bethesda games, which I always usually get bored of as partway through the game your character is more powerful than the game curve and every enemy is toast even on highest difficulty.  So thumbs up to Two Worlds for this, and I hope to see tough, non level-scaled enemies in Two Worlds 3 also.

There are lots of other great things in this game but these are the 2 that really stick in my mind.  Horses and boats are great also come to think of it.

Anyway this game should be getting 90%+ I think on recommendations, its being brought down by the DRM unfortunatley, but IMHO it's well worth jumping through the hoops to play this amazing game.

reviewText:
I'm not going to pretend this game is great, it even borders on bad at times but if youre a big wrpg fan you might let some of the bad things slide and see it for what it does well.
Controls are clunky and animations are stiff, but the Gameplay is solid and character progression is good, you have 3 options in how you handle combat, ranged, melee and magic, ranged is probably the worst but i didn't really experience much of it, melee is fairly basic but the skills you can get make it a little better with time, i didn't start to enjoy it until i started parrying(hitting just after blocking) and using my skills more.
Magic is insanely good in this game, it works by combining different effect cards with different elements to create your own spells, i'm not sure how many spells there are in the game but a lot of them are pretty unique and creative.
The story is pretty average apart from the ending, i don't want to spoil it but the last boss is really dissapointing since you don't even fight him head on.
Sidequests on the other hand are great and reminded me of oblivion in some ways, although not nearly as good, you have different guilds that have different storylines that vary in length and then there are a bunch of quests in the world that are both interesting and even pretty funny at times.
Graphically it's a mixed bag, aesthetically it's great, the enviroments are varied and pretty unique for a wrpg, you go from an egyptian savannah area to some sort of asian(Korean or Chinese) jungle and finally to a swamp, the assets and environments are good looking but other aspects like animations and character models are pretty bad.
One final thing to note is that you have to register an account at the beggining of the game to use the multiplayer, the registration is incredibly intrusive and personal if i remember correctly and i saw that a lot of people marked the game as not reccomended because of it, which i consider completely justified, if you however decide to try the mp(and that's if it's still online)you're going to get a pretty great psuedo mmo tier experience with loads of content and even a village manager later on.

reviewText: Over 20 years of PC gaming and I haven't had a game blue screen this much since at least 97. Beyond the crashing and blue screens it's plagued with glitches that rival Sonic 06, a multitude of other nonsense including bad voice acting, weird environment detection, clunky combat and this weird fish eye effect with the camera that makes me want to gouge my own eyes out. Sure the game looks alright, and it may even appeal to some but if you want smooth gameplay and a story that does something different while giving the impression that it's a polished work of art, I don't think this is what you're looking for. I'd reccomend only getting this game if it happens to be in a bundle with better games. Other than that, probably best to avoid it.

reviewText:
The game is great. I find it rather funny and entertaining, and my only complaint is the framerate.
I'm gonna be apologetic about some things that others have criticized:

The voice acting:
It's not that bad. Certainly better than the majority of anime dubs out there, and really, it's pretty much on par with the voice acting in Skyrim. Which while no huge feat, is still kind of the industry standard.

The dialogue:
Is it perfect? No. But it is pretty dang funny. The charatcers are full of quips and one-liners with a lot of homages (You're a little short for a City Guard aren't you?) and a LOT of self-mockery, especially directed at the previous game in the series, which are subtle, but you'll catch if you play them back to back.

The fighting:
It's pretty straight forward attack-button mashing mostly. But when you do come up against particularly tough opponents you can usually find some way to beat them. Otherwise: go level up. It's an RPG. So of course the mobs that are hard at the beginning (Varns: which are Mummy III army of Anubis style jackal-men) become paper thin foes by 6 hours in.

The plot:
Save the girl. Defeat the evil Emperor. Bad guys from the first game are now the good guys. Pretty standard. Is that bad? I don't think so. It's still an enjoyable story. If you're looking a novel, complex plotline, GO READ A BOOK! It's all plot and no grind! Want suggestions? Message me, I'll give you lists. So unless you're looking to be blown away by some unexpected seldom-before-seen tale of intrigue, wizardry, and shenanigans, it's a good story.

As for the sidequest stories. They're ridiculously over the top, asinine, or just straight up obvious comedic relief. One mercenary mission request is a parent and daughter locked in a cellar because there are angry ostriches trying to kill the daughter by touching her with their feathers and causing an allergic reaction. They sent the letter by carrier pidgeon. Is this serious? Clearly not. To those saying the game's stories are stupid: lighten up. Laugh at the game. Laugh at the genre. They're really picking on RPGs as a genre in this game.

The mechanics:
Plays like a hack'n'slash brawler. I like hack'n'slash brawlers. It can be a bit clunky at times, with your character sometimes crouch to sneak instead of running for his life, but you can fix that by changing the key-bindings I believe.

Lastly, the Personal Info requirements:
It's your name and address. All public information anyway. All information you've already put into Steam likely more than once. Do you really the Polish game designers care that much about you that they're going to stalk you, or ruin their business by stealing your identity? Or send you snailmail? No. It's for commercial data collection. Statistics. By knowing your address, age, and sex, they can precisely gauge who is buying their stuff and adjust marketing accordingly. That's it.

reviewText:
Two Worlds was an interesting fantasy game, it was flawed but there were objects and systems in it that I really liked. Two Worlds 2 picks up a little bit after where the original left off and you are still just as much in the dark as the first one. Gandohar is doing somethin evil, but his motives are never really explained nor what has happened in between the two games.

One thing that really bugs me about this game is that a lot of the things in this game have to be worked around and serve no purpose other than to make things needlessly difficult. For example, spell usage in the previous game was a useful way to mix swordplay with elemental attacks and healing to save you from death. In this game spells can only be used with a staff and the system for using spells in convoluted and requires lots of study and experimentation. Spell cards can be bought, but they are ridiculously expensive.

Movement is blockier, akward, and running is hard to control or stop. Horse riding can help you cover long patches of land quickly, but the horse is hard to turn and jump with, and you can easily lose track of him while on foot.

Finally, the overlay system of the last game (which let you combine two of the same weapons or armor pieces to make an improved version) is replaced with a crafting system where gear is improved with materials found by breaking down other gear. While not worse than the old system, it's still another unessecary thing to worry about.

Overall, I would reccomend you play the first game before you play this one otherwise you may be unhappy with the systems and mechanics and not give it a try.

This game wants to be an Elder Scrolls (fanboy) so bad but just cannot pull it off. This game HAS great  potential and it is sad to see that it has been over looked.

AMD GPU USERS. After install restart the machine and it should run fine. Nvidia had their dirty fingers in this and well
date:
enough said.

Combat is bad and so are the menu's. Magic is over complicated and very little is explained during game play. At times I did not know what to do or where to go.  Goof around a little and it will come to you.

This game needs modders in a bad way. Modders fix what devs just don't get and that is needed here in the worst of ways (like Skyrim did.)

I really like the game despite the weakness that is displayed at every possible moment. It just has that feel that I get with the early Elder Scrolls. Perhaps there will be a redux or modders will get involved and make this game great."

reviewText: First and foremost if you plan on playing this game Activate" and "Register" are two different things. You must activate the game by internet or phone with your cd-key
date: but make sure to uncheck the "register" box so you won't have to deal with the hassle of filling out a form with all your personal info.\n\nI had an issue with this game regarding lag or slowdown where the game would go from running smooth 60fps then lagging heavily then back to smooth. I was able to resolve it by opening Nvidia Control panel and manually setting the profile of this game to run using "Adaptive V-Sync"
recommended:
"Triple Buffering ON" and "Single Display Performance". It still slightly lags in parts of the intro where you escape the prison but overall fixes the major slowdown issues across the game.

As for the game itself it has its charms and shortcomings. On the positive side the graphics hold up quite well in 2016 with max settings and environments have detailed design. You can have three active sets of gear so switching between fighting styles is easy. Voice over work is a massive improvement over the original game and feels more polished.

On the bad side of things the game relies heavily on combat and it is very clunky and frustating. For example if you melee and move while you press the attack button for combos
hoursPlayed: it will break the chain. You must stand still for your attacks to chain. Smaller faster enemies will do hit and run tactics where they will charge attack and immediately run away a few yards
voteText:
making counters useless. Then there are enemies that will swarm you and attack you repeatedly and all you can really do is block and run away. The game also throws in random enemies that are much stronger then the rest. Problem is you can't really tell which ones they are until they hit you twice while you block and kill you. The animations aren't great either. Attacks look like that don't have any impact and your character looks like he is just flailing his arms around. Auto target is extremely unreliable with a high chance you will be dislodged and attack open space.

I haven't played too far into the game to get a strong grasp of the story but so far the prologue doesn't really offer anything special. The first bunch of characters that help you on your quest seem decent but the main character is annoying. I don't understand why he is so weak that he has to learn how to use a sword/staff/bow and he just talks way too much.

I haven't run into any major glitches (ie. crashing/corrupt saves) but a minor one is during dialog between the characters the lines would get cut off and the next character would begin talking.

Overall it's hard to give a definitive yes or no to recommending the game. I would recommend getting the game absolutely if it's on sale. I picked it up for a couple of bucks. It's a fun distraction if you are patient enough and give it a chance.

However
helpfulPercent: if you had just finished games like Skyrim or the Witcher 2/3
votesHelpful: you might feel like this game is nothing but mediocre compared to those polished amazing experiences."

reviewText: Two Worlds II gets rid of the best part of Two Worlds - exploration. The original game was a rough RPG, it had many flaws, but it was the exploration that made it a decent game. The sequel is no longer open world, and instead it focuses on storyline, which however, is as bad as in the first game. The NPCs are just as shallow, and the combat remains the same - okay, but nothing special. In consequence, we are left with a game that is average at best, because the excitement of discovering new areas is dimnished by the fact that everything is led by the story, and hence the player cannot go sideways, try to fight much more powerful enemies in hope of much better loot than he is supposed to find. Two Worlds II becomes just an average game with nothing special. I would recommend it only for those who already completed Two Worlds and other good RPGs and have nothing to play. It's okay to kill some time, however, not really worth much. Two Worlds II is a huge disappointment. Instead of improving gameplay in the sequel, developers took away the only thing that made the original game good.

reviewText:
I have mixed feelings about this game. The world is beautiful, and the main quests (and some side quests) involve actual C&C, and allow you to take sides here and there, which adds a lot to the story. There are often surprises to be discovered, when there is more than meets the eye to a quest giver or his motives. However, other than that the game suffers from almost every common problem seen in a fully open world RPG. For one thing, it's a lootfest. You'll be collecting a huge sack of stuff that you'll never need. Inexplicably, that includes a whole lot of buffers for situations you'll never encounter. (I really wish that developers would give some thought to the looting. Make it worthwhile. Give me something really powerful to buy. Give me a situation where I'll need a frost buffer.) Secondly, the story telling is choppy at times. I've finished the game but I wouldn't be able to explain the plot to anyone, just the same way I would be able to explain the plot of a poorly edited B-movie. Not that it's all bad. Sometimes the story can really grab your attention, especially when you're unexpectedly trapped or surprised to find out the identity of the serial killer you were looking for. The people who made this game can tell a good story, but they don't do it consistently. It's almost like the problem was organizational rather than lack of talent. An RPG with C&C is very hard to plan, and this game is a bit rough around the edges as a result. The story could also benefit from real professional writing, and some more complex lore. The lore of 2W2 is very thin and lacks a sense of politics and philosophy. The societies it portrays smack of modern day social norms rather than the humility, grit and fear of the medieval world. It's obvious that the game writers have played The Witcher, because they (loosely) copied some of its stories, but 2W2 lacks the unity of that game and its atmosphere and creative direction. That being said, some of the side quests can be unexpectedly deep and long, which was a pleasant surprise.

The graphics, as I already said, are beautiful. The vistas are nice. The grass. The water. The shadows. Light shining between the branches. Aside from the nasty screen tearing, it looks better than many more recent RPG titles. Unfortunately, it looks like they were cheap on artistry. The design of everything is cliche. Your mage wears a pointy hat that makes him look like Disney's Merlin.

The game features three continents and a number of smaller islands. It looks huge, until you find out that the biggest continent is used mostly for multi-player (which I admittedly haven't tried yet). The assets are reused in a subtle way so they don't get boring. For example, there is a university, and then there are ruins of a university in a dark place called the Swallows. They're almost copies of the same thing, but this is difficult to notice. I wish, though, the devs had made exploration a bit more rewarding. There are too many places where there is just a dead end or some nearly useless loot.

The combat, while fun at times, lacks tactics. I played as a mage, and most of the fights in the game consisted of me casting a summon spell that surrounded the enemies with my summoned decoys that trapped them. Then I zapped these enemies with seeking fire balls. Really, this was a way of exploiting the stupidity of the AI, the fact that the AI cannot push over or walk over another (even much weaker) character and also the fact that the collision detector doesn't detect friendly fire and my fireballs pass right though the summons. In other words, 90% of the fights in the game are ridiculous. The combat system is also prone to the standard run back and forth spamming health potions abuse that is so common in this kind of game. It's made all the easier by the fact that your character can outrun anything. I should also add that the health bars, magic bars and any other bars in the game are about 2-5 times as long as they should be. A typical fight will require 20-50 fireball spells for a single enemy, late in the game.

The magic system is a bit innovative. You can cast fireball summons, for example. Theoretically, you can combine dozens of spell cards into almost any elaborate spell. In practice, however, only some combinations actually work as a spell. If you play as a mage you'll be firing guided missiles" for the whole game and not much more.

The game adds a few interesting touches here and there. Your character talks to himself in some situations
date: and even makes fun of enemies. You can ride a horse

reviewText:
Two Worlds II is a kinda fun rpg whit alot of unused potential.

The game is obvious a port and the mechanics are a bit clunky and not as smooth and responsive as it could be. The Story is a bit unrealistic and kinda shallow, Some might even guess how its gona end before geting halfway through the story!

When it comes to the Story it's linearly and seems to try cover alot of diffrent cultures (European, Asian and Arabian-African) and most of the time you need to help others with random tedious quest in order to progress. The dialogue in most conversations are boring and uninteresting and even cuts itself off or doesent fit the mouth animation on evry charachter, but the most unsatisfying is the main characters bland voice which more or less kill the mood of evry conversation whit the npc's.

One thing where Two Worlds II stands out from most rpg's is the skill tree or development, you are not forced to go down one specific route but have the option to mix magic with stealth and/or other abilitys, for example you could become a two handed water mage (might not be the optimal route but it exist) but sadly the strength lies in the mage class where you can create and customise extremly powerful spells which makes the other classes/abilitys inferior to the mage class/abilitys.
one thing alsoe worth noting is that the monster level does not scale well and most of the time the enemys are way to easy or kills you in one hit but the Ai isnt that good which make surviving kinda easy regardless.
One thing that realy bothers me is the potential of exploring the game could have had. There are boats you could use to explore the sea but there isnt alot to se in the sea and the boats are not a fast method of travling even the horses arent that great of travling becouse your character has a pretty got pace to his speed and horses can be a bother to find and they cant fast travel with you.

in the end the game is still kinda fun its just sad that it have hidden potential and the story that isn't interesting enough. for an rpg i would give it 5,0/10 becouse there are some elements to it that makes the game somewhat diffrent from other rpg's and works well in the rpg genre!

reviewText: If you like a story with a challenge that you will have to kill every monster and do every quest just to be able to kill things still later then the story part is for you. The online is better than the story in my opinion. This game has one of my favorite spell crafting systems in it ever. You want to make a spell that lets you walk on water, then go ahead. You want a fire ball spell that blinds people and summons 10 skeletons all at the same time, go for it. The spell crafting can be a little overwhelming at first but once you get used to it you can be very op very fast (especially necro tree). There is also a bit of a econ sim with a built in city builder where you make your own little town if you want to. I got this game at full price and have no regrets.

reviewText: Two Worlds 2 можно порекомендовать в качестве реабилитационной терапии после недавней Готики. Она на самом деле лучше, прилизаннее, лишена чудовищных багов. Для многих она подействовала действительно как бальзам на душу. К несчастью, при всем старании разработчиков убрать недостатки предыдущей части новые «элементы» резво бьют по рукам, отбивая желание знакомства с этим безумно неудобным шаблонным миром. Спасти ситуацию мог мультиплеер, однако он заведомо обречен на провал. Сервера пустуют. Мультиплеер первой части являлся настоящим пристанищем лагов и читеров, и, несмотря на все заверения, Two Worlds 2 унаследовала все эти черты. Чего стоит только тот факт, что статы игроков хранятся на локальных компьютерах. Несложно представить последствия этой ситуации. Все, что есть в Two Worlds 2 – прилизанное визуальное оформление и отсутствие багов. Последнее на сегодняшний день – настоящая редкость, так что этот факт может являться стимулом для прохождения игры до конца, в том случае если закрыть глаза на неадекватный интерфейс и пустые диалоги. RealityPump «перестарались» – других слов для подведения итога попросту не найти.

reviewText:
+ Reworked combat places emphasis on action over animation. Deeper magic system
+ Good quest variety
+ Music is still great, voice acting is improved
+ Lots of minigames that adhere to the experience

~ Armor and weapons can no longer be upgraded endlessly
~ Alchemy no longer has any negative effects. Once you can make a good channeling potion, you'll forget what dying was like
~ Texture quality is improved, but everything else looks awkward. There is way too much bloom and motion blur
~ Horse control is improved, but mounted combat is gone. Enemies can now be run over
~ Quests now use automatic map markers to show the way. Though it's nice to see where I have to go, I found myself rarely having to actually think to complete quests. It's an imperfect solution that could have been solved through better writing

- Game is short and linear. Main quest must now be done in specific order. 4 chapters, and the last 2 can be done in about an hour each. Game tries to cover this up by having a steep difficulty curve. It makes sidequests feel compulsory, as this is where most xp can be found. Boosting your level this way is the only way to make the main quest a fair challenge
- Map is much more limited than it looks. Large amounts of land and sea have little of interest and/or are inaccesible. A lot of the time that I've logged on the game has been simply to explore areas that I later found were pointless to explore
- Stupid AI. Got a bounty for defending myself in a city. Many enemies can be safespotted
- Lots of glitches. That bounty I just mentioned; I got it for fighting back against a character who was supposed to stop asking me for money after a quest. Quest ended, and whenever I got too close to him, I had to choose whether to pay him or fight him

Overall, it's sort of meh". Drops the ball on a lot of the stuff that the first game did fine
date: while introducing mechanics that feel fresh and more user-friendly. Not sure whether I recommend it
recommended: unless you also plan on getting the DLC
hoursPlayed: in which case it's definitely worth a try."
voteText: November 10, 2015

reviewText: One of the most well-designed CRPG experiences you'll find. Not the best writing (though good writing) and not the best graphics (though good graphics) but the way that everything WORKS is fantastic. There is no such thing as vendor trash, because you can always break items for crafting materials; the magic system is modular and interesting; bows have autoaiming for close enemies to allow being an archer to be fun again and your arrows never run out because making more arrows is dull and TW2 is never, ever dull.\n\nOne quest involves a woman trying to feed you to her zombie husband. Buy this game.

reviewText:
Two Worlds II is a rather enjoyable experience. While it doesn't certainly have the quality BioWare or Bethesda RPGs tend to have, it has some unique features that make it worth looking into, at least.

One of these is the combat. The combat in this game is very fluid and diverse. You can choose to play as a warrior, an archer or a mage. There are no preset classes, you gradually become better at your chosen role through leveling up the needed attributes and skills. Sort of like Oblivion in that regard. However you have a set of active combat skills as well, and these vary greatly, from breaking someone's block to countering someone's attack while you're doing the blocking yourself. Even when switching from blunt to slash weapons. Archery is usually done via auto aiming, but the active combat skills that an archer can use will require you to use manual aiming, something which is very welcome. The cream of the crop though, is magic. If you've ever played Magicka, you know how crazy you can get by combining spells to make something truly unique. Two Worlds II? It's the same way. You can customize and build your spells thoroughly, and it never gets old, providing a really rewarding way to play.

However, if you're a completionist, and upgrade your equipment well, which is done by destroying unused weapons and armor to gather raw materials to reforge them as upgrades to your current set, (very neat feature) this game will be really easy save for the final battle, thankfully, which is actually challenging.

Having at least two different forms of combat is important at any given time for the enemies in this game are plenty and each have their own specific weaknesses. While some will die anyway by just button mashing, it'll take a lot longer if you use the wrong weapon.

The plot is.... to say the least, confusing. The pacing is all over the place and I was disappointed with the abrupt and sudden ending, though you can choose to play after the game ends, thankfully, either to tie loose ends or to experience the pirate expansion. (i've not played it so no opinion on it) You do get to understand it fully by the time you're done, but I do wonder if one would have needed to play the first Two Worlds to know everything.

The world is quite large and varied with several continents and remote islands with loot ready to explore. You can actually buy a boat and be able to sail it in this game at your own will, something I really got into, except the content for this was sorely lacking. And while I did mention the world is large, which it is, some of it are just smoke and mirrors as 70% of the largest continent isn't even accessible, all you'll get is a Can't go this way" message and you get teleported out. -_-

There are horse races and several faction quests
date: complete with a gladiatorial arena series of battles. This game took a LOT from Oblivion
recommended: but it's different enough to not come off as a ripoff.\n\nThe graphics in this game are quite pleasing to the eye
voteText:
it has a LOT of options to customize it perfectly should you choose to do so. Nothing but thumbs up from me in this regard.

The music was okay. Nothing special about it. It did its job but sometimes it could get quite repetitive.

The voice acting was not that great. No performances came off as fantastic to me
helpfulPercent: while some other few cases were completely crap. Your main character loved to sound tough
votesHelpful: and he NEVER
votesTotal: NEVER shuts up. Whether he finds or kills an enemy
votesFunny: opens a chest and goes swimming
commentsCount: he'll say one of 5 lines every single time. Get ready to hear him repeat them hundreds of times before the game's finished
column16: which by the way is a bit long
column17: though I seriously expected it to be a lot longer given the game world.\n\nIf you've went through all the greats in the RPG genre and need a fix for some more
column18: you could do a lot worse than picking up Two Worlds II. While it certainly doesn't feel like a polished game
column19: it's got its heart in the right place."

reviewText:
As the only person I know who finished the original Two Worlds game (a notroriously awful game which truly was a chore to get through) I was sceptical about playing Two Worlds 2.  I managed to pick it up cheaply as part of a bundle however and decided I had nothing to lose by giving it a go.

TW2 is not a perfect game by any means but it is a vast improvement upon the first one.  The graphics are absolutely stunning, the dialogue is much better (althought still a bit cringey), the storyline is much easier to follow and the mechanics have really been cleaned up.  I would say the game's environments are one of it's stongest suit, something which even the first game did particularly well with.  With sprawling savannahs, treacherous tropical rainforests, gorgeous beaches and insidious marshes TW2 has one of the most diverse maps I've ever seen in a game.

Other Strong Points

- Crafting system (Being able to constantly upgrade your weapon is something I loved about the first game).
- Range of weaponry (I really do love a game where I can go from a cutlass to a katana to a halberd to a polearm!)

A Few Negatives

- Controls can feel a bit awkward, but still much better than the first game!
- Dialogue is a bit cringey.
- Menus are slightly difficult to navigate, especially the quest log.

Don't feel deterred from playing this if you haven't played the original (I played it and I couldn't tell you what the heck it was about) and it is a solid RPG that is definately worth a go.

In short; not perfect but better than the first one by far.
7/10

reviewText: I wanted my money back 20 minutes into the game. The only thing salvagable i got from the bundle package was the tower defense. In my opinion they had good intentions, but the game lack a sort of uniqueness that draws a player in.

reviewText: There are a lots of improvements since Two Worlds 1, graphics is now awesome, the terrain, and vegetation doesn't have repetitive rock/field textures, the maps are big, tons of quests are waiting for the player to complete them, i solved all i've found, took me 65 hours to finish everything, which is not too long, and not too short time. The quality of quests are various, there are some traditional kill x creature ones too, bring potions, etc, but overall were entertaining. Some bugs in quests made some headache. The fighting system is not a big deal, but the crafting system allows to upgrade and recycle weapons, the armor sets can be mixed colored, shaped for the player's tastes.\nThe multiplayer doesn't worth a word.\nMusic tracks are nicely composed, brings more color in the game, and the story is not ending here! However, the TW3 is on hold atm, since devs have other games in development, personally i can't wait to see what will happen next.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
funny how 90% of the bad review-accounts have less than 1hour playtime...you didn't even get passed the tutorial XD How do you wanna give a good review? Ridicolous...
And seriously, everyone who played Two Worlds 1 knows that those games aren't about a good main story line, its about all the sidequests and the discovery of the HUGE open world (after the tutorial it's open :)), I have 12h+ game time and I'm still in act 1, and I not even close to get to act2.

it has also some features other good RPG's don't have e.g.:
-you can create your own spells with many, many, many variations
-3 equipment sets, so you can choose easily between for example a melle-, magic-, bow-build
-skill gems for equipment
..


Ofc it has some downsides:
-registration is kinda weird but seriously who is so naive to put his right name in anyways?

-horse riding is completely non-intuitive. You have to press W the whole time, than the horse rides slowly in the direction you look. By pressing the right mouse button you accelerate, and you change direction by where you look, I don't even use A or D. And this continuous clicking and the fact that the smallest branch of a tree can stop you are annoying.

Also funny that some people don't recommend this game because they had to enter a ONE-TIME serial code, LOL. It's a game from 2011, back than it was normal... The mimimi level is really high nowadays XD

Conclusion: Like all games it has some downsides, but I really enjoy playing it and can recommend.
Btw got the velvet-edition for less than 4€ on sale..was worth it :)

reviewText:
The game is fairly solid overall, and wondefully captures that big-world feel with a suprisingly solid sense of realism. I actually enjoyed it so far after spending a few hours on it.

Sure, it does have a couple drawbacks (but what games don't?).

Namely...

- I feel the character control should have been made a lot tighter & snappier, without that silly sliding stop also. This would have made such a huge diff. It isn't super bad now, but it could have definitely been implemented better. I'd say this is my number one issue with this game.

- The registration nonsense of the game is just a needless PITA (although thankfully it's only a one-time thing).

But make no mistake about it, the graphics and atmosphere are absolutely spell-binding in this game, with solid character modelling and voice-acting. Story is so-so, passable.

And for the low sale price, you won't find anything better out there, that's for sure.

I'd rate this game a solid 7/10 as it stands (would have been higher with snappier character/combat control).

reviewText:
Hear me out before you brush me off, the game is amazing... On console. I've played it for a while on Xbox 360 and saw it on sale yesterday. Thought I should buy it to have some fun again and possibly remake a character, who knows, its >$3.

But I've spent 2 and a half hours trying to get the d@mn game to activate. Spent a long time researching, even contimplated using one of those shady key generators. After a while, I discovered that they are making a GNU/Linux port for the game next month, which will also fix a few errors. (Now, I'm already using Linux, and emulating the game over WineHQ, so seeing this gives me some hope)

What I'm saying is, don't buy the game yet. Wait a while until after next month and look at the reviews... If they get better somewhere, and you don't see any complaints about the abhorant activation process, BUY IT.

(Triple activation is downright annoying and berating to those who actually purchase the game. Some people have to retype in their activation code directly after loading screens... Again, wtf.)

So as for now, DO NOT BUY THIS GAME.

(If the problem has been fixed, I'll delete this review and give it a thumbs up.)

reviewText: While the combat is clunky to say the least, once you start finding books to unlock more spell types and abilities, the game becomes far more interesting. Combine this with a fairly basic crafting system and you have a decent RPG. I will say this though, there are several bugs that have burrowed their way into this game, whether it is ground polygons having flipped normals causing you to drop into an endless sea, accidentally getting stuck inside of a boulder inside a cave and having to re-load or having enemies getting stuck inside the environment. All and all, 6/10 here. It would get a 7/10 but the dialog is painfully bad at times and it completely takes me out of the experience.

reviewText:
If you are one of the many who played the original Two Worlds for as long as you could tolerate it before deciding it was a horrific waste of good code, do not let that experience keep you away from Two Worlds 2.

I have been playing RPG's (pnp and pc/console) for a quarter century now and I have to say that I love just about every type of pc rpg, from diablo clones to the Wizardy series, and the Elder Scrolls to Neverwinter Nights.  Like many rpg fans, I played the original Two Worlds, and like many, the game cd for the 360 became a drink coaster, and I have to admit that it is a much better coaster than it was a game.

Two Worlds 2 is not that.  While it will only show that I have an hour or two played, I previously owned the game for the 360, and liked it enough that I picked it up on sale here on Steam.  If you set your expectations properly, Two Worlds 2 is a great purchase.  Realize that you are not buying Skyrim.  This is not one of the top ten pc RPG's of all time.  At the same time, it is not Two Worlds either.

Two Worlds 2 is an enjoyable RPG experience, with a fair bit of replay value.  There are far worse ways to spend your money at Steam, and at a sale price, this game is a steal looking at it from a hours played/dollars spent ratio.

reviewText:
There is lots to love here for fans of the sandboxy-RPG realm, I suppose. I'm no authority on the genre, but the combat and magic system, for example, actually offers a superior level of fun in some ways than that of titans like Skyrim, IMHO.

The musical 'mini-game' deserves a paragraph unto itself. It's Medieval Guitar Hero, with song arrangements that are actually quite inspired and a surprising joy to dabble in with the various bards-at-large in the realm.

But at the end of the day, TWII seems kind of hamstrung by flat voice acting, repetitive sound design, and a maddeningly middle-of-the-road stance on how seriously it wants to be taken.

At times this tongue-in-cheek, knowing stance works in the game's — and the gamer's — favour, giving it a disarmingly approachable feel for an 'epic' RPG. At other moments, however, you may find yourself desperately wishing it could make up its mind to stop pulling punches and fully embrace one way or the other.

reviewText:
I would give this game a 6/10.

The story...very enjoyable and entertaining side quests let you meet some very colorful characters.

The Graphics...it is a bit buggy at times, but makes up for that in great scenery and wildlife graphics. I wish they had done as well with the human graphics, they are not horrible but could have been so much better. The water graphics... WOW the best I have seen in a game!

The Fighting system...great balance of attack, parry, and defence that makes you think and time your moves for the best outcome. Very enjoyable!

The Quest system...very in depth with clues along the way and map marks to help get you where you need to go.

The Transportation...boats...horses...teleports...what else does one need? :)

The Magic system...fun but complicated. You can create your own spell combinations using 'cards' that you find while exploring, hunting, and buying from merchants. It makes for some fun effects if you have invested in the skill far enough to cast what you have created.

The Alchemy system...fun to experiment and make your own recipes that you can save and click a scroll to create later with ease. Water walking potion? Squee!

The Crafting system...on the fly and anywhere crafting! Dismantle what you don't need for components and use them to upgrade the stuff you are going to use! And don't forget the dyes...what color do you want to wear? Find dyes at merchants and use them to our hearts delight!

Overall I really enjoyed this game...though it is no Gothic, Dragon Age or Skyrim...it was still fun!

Mods...I would recommend the Two Worlds Merged, mod. It expands the World into one large map with no barriers, adds more dye options, an in depth add on series of quests that are quite fun and add hours of gameplay...and many other features that add to the fun!

reviewText:
The best description I can give for this is the Lidl version of 'The Witcher'.
That' not fair.
The Tesco's version of 'The Witcher'

I base this on the fact you can do melle combat, magic, archery and alchemy (cooking up your own potions from what you can scavenge) and like The Witcher you will be required to be proficient in all of these areas, not just specialising in one.
There are original touches such as the use of crafting to break down scavenged items into constituent parts to be used to upgrade existing weapons, and the story was interesting.

Plus the menu is easy to grasp and simple, and graphically it's nice to look at too.

If you like RPG's and can get it for less than a fiver it's well worth adding to your game library.

reviewText:
Two worlds (the first game) had a huge map, yet it felt janky in every way a game can feel janky. Two worlds 2, has a tiny map, tiny islands, and for a game with guilds and a supposedly open world, does not have a great deal to discover. So in the end, both games have drawbacks. If you want a huge world, get the first game, just be willing to overlook 1000 different janky elements. If you want a more console, streamlined, slimmed down, rpg time, get this game. It looks better, plays better, and the content while significantly reduced, is of a higher quality level.

7.5/10 for the core game, 7/10 for the expansion which has better writing but a smaller world and a desaturated look that feels a bit washed out and unexiting visually.

If you want a skyrim extremely-lite experiance, then you might find that here and have a damn good time.

Also, the game has its own original ways of tackling common RPG features, such as magic, armed combat etc. I fully recommend this title.

reviewText:
There is lots to love here for fans of the sandboxy-RPG realm, I suppose. I'm no authority on the genre, but the combat and magic system, for example, actually offers a superior level of fun in some ways than that of titans like Skyrim, IMHO.

The musical 'mini-game' deserves a paragraph unto itself. It's Medieval Guitar Hero, with song arrangements that are actually quite inspired and a surprising joy to dabble in with the various bards-at-large in the realm.

But at the end of the day, TWII seems kind of hamstrung by flat voice acting, repetitive sound design, and a maddeningly middle-of-the-road stance on how seriously it wants to be taken.

At times this tongue-in-cheek, knowing stance works in the game's — and the gamer's — favour, giving it a disarmingly approachable feel for an 'epic' RPG. At other moments, however, you may find yourself desperately wishing it could make up its mind to stop pulling punches and fully embrace one way or the other.

reviewText:
I would give this game a 6/10.

The story...very enjoyable and entertaining side quests let you meet some very colorful characters.

The Graphics...it is a bit buggy at times, but makes up for that in great scenery and wildlife graphics. I wish they had done as well with the human graphics, they are not horrible but could have been so much better. The water graphics... WOW the best I have seen in a game!

The Fighting system...great balance of attack, parry, and defence that makes you think and time your moves for the best outcome. Very enjoyable!

The Quest system...very in depth with clues along the way and map marks to help get you where you need to go.

The Transportation...boats...horses...teleports...what else does one need? :)

The Magic system...fun but complicated. You can create your own spell combinations using 'cards' that you find while exploring, hunting, and buying from merchants. It makes for some fun effects if you have invested in the skill far enough to cast what you have created.

The Alchemy system...fun to experiment and make your own recipes that you can save and click a scroll to create later with ease. Water walking potion? Squee!

The Crafting system...on the fly and anywhere crafting! Dismantle what you don't need for components and use them to upgrade the stuff you are going to use! And don't forget the dyes...what color do you want to wear? Find dyes at merchants and use them to our hearts delight!

Overall I really enjoyed this game...though it is no Gothic, Dragon Age or Skyrim...it was still fun!

Mods...I would recommend the Two Worlds Merged, mod. It expands the World into one large map with no barriers, adds more dye options, an in depth add on series of quests that are quite fun and add hours of gameplay...and many other features that add to the fun!

reviewText:
If you are one of the many who played the original Two Worlds for as long as you could tolerate it before deciding it was a horrific waste of good code, do not let that experience keep you away from Two Worlds 2.

I have been playing RPG's (pnp and pc/console) for a quarter century now and I have to say that I love just about every type of pc rpg, from diablo clones to the Wizardy series, and the Elder Scrolls to Neverwinter Nights.  Like many rpg fans, I played the original Two Worlds, and like many, the game cd for the 360 became a drink coaster, and I have to admit that it is a much better coaster than it was a game.

Two Worlds 2 is not that.  While it will only show that I have an hour or two played, I previously owned the game for the 360, and liked it enough that I picked it up on sale here on Steam.  If you set your expectations properly, Two Worlds 2 is a great purchase.  Realize that you are not buying Skyrim.  This is not one of the top ten pc RPG's of all time.  At the same time, it is not Two Worlds either.

Two Worlds 2 is an enjoyable RPG experience, with a fair bit of replay value.  There are far worse ways to spend your money at Steam, and at a sale price, this game is a steal looking at it from a hours played/dollars spent ratio.

reviewText: Although I usually try to give games several hours to draw me in, I find myself completely unable to do so with this one.  While the game doesn't look terribly bad, the animations and combat are abysmal at best.  The voice acting is decent but the conversations involve people going through one of two really low quality animations that just look like everyone is shrugging.  The default key bindings are incredibly odd and while they are rebindable, the way the combat works makes it redundant.  Going into stealth mode requires you to be standing completely still, as does blocking.  If you are moving at all you will instead start sprinting.  Targetting is hit and miss and I simply did not want to continue playing after the short time I had with the game.

reviewText:
I really want it to be good. It's a huge game. You spend a lot of time in the begining on two main islands. Both feel pretty large. But if you zoom out of the map you'll realise theres a whole other island you haven't even been to yet that's five times as big as the other two islands combined. That's a great feeling.

But oh my gosh is this game hard to control. You are so clunky! Everything is clunky! The melee combat is just gross to experience, range is either way too easy or way too hard and doesn't feel natural either way, magic is fun to mess around with but is also hard to use in combat especially if you have allies with you. That fire bomb spell doesn't know what the word friendly means. Doors are hard to open, jumping is grotesque, running looks and feels stupid especially if you prefer to carry a staff or polearm. Even the simplest actions like opening chests or picking up loose items is difficult. The loading times for containers is way too long and breaks up the whole game. I can't express enough how clunky this game feels. For a game with so much content, i'm straight up mad the fighting actually makes it unenjoyable to play.

It's not even like this game is that old. There are no excuses. Especially since the first in the series had the same problem and they failed to fix it. And the fact the game freezes while it loads the next area sometimes is really annoying.

On a positive note, this instalment improved upon the first Two Worlds in a lot of ways. The world is bigger, there are more kinds of enemies, cooler weapons, better story, necromancy is legal yay! However, it's just as clunky as the first game and really quite hard to play because of it. If the mobility in Two Worlds didn't bother you then you will definitely like this game. If however you're used to rpg's like Skyrim get ready for pure movement hell.

reviewText:
Understand that this is an action RPG that focuses on killing stuff, getting loot, and levelling up so you can kill more stuff.  If that appeals to you, go for it.  It appeals to me.
+ Very good graphics
+ Interesting character customization
+ Weapon/armor upgrades are fun and require some strategy
+ Combat system is relatively simple but fun
+ Places to go (open world!)
+ Lots of things to kill and kill and kill
+ Loot
+ Horse races!

Cons:
- A story so bad, it will leave you staring blankly into the distance for about an hour if you finish the game
- Possibly the *worst* voice-acting *ever* in any game of any kind.  Microsoft Sam would have been a better choice.
- Dialog is silly at best, incomprehensible at worst

reviewText:
Okay, so, Two Worlds II. Quite the odd name there, just like the rest of the game itself.

Unfortunately, this is one of those games that suffer from the size of their project scope: the final product is extremely hampered, there are many loose ends in the game. It initially gives you the impression that it's a vast world that you can explore and find out all sorts of interesting things, until you figure out that there are many pointless/unfinished locations. Most of the dungeons are copy-pasted a lot (or rather, the whole game itself is), without much effort to make them diversified. This is made worse by the looting system, which makes the content of virtually all chests random. Very few locales/dungeons have chests with unique loot, which is extremely disappointing. Don't expect anything better from monster/boss loot, which is also randomized most of the time.

Some of the quests are interesting in terms of dialogue, but honestly, most of the NPC dialogue is boring, so you'll most likely find yourself skipping it a lot. At some points it takes jabs at common RPG/videogame conventions and tropes, so whoever wrote it has some awareness of the typical RPG designs' quirks. Including their own.

Despite the game's broad variety of courier-boy quests (yes, you, delivery man, go murder some ostriches and fetch me the grass inside their stomatchs), the game's story itself is linear. However, at a certain point in the game, the entire game becomes much more restricted: suddenly you can't teleport anymore, and you're restricted to this small area and do a handful of quests because the devs cannot allow you to leave this fenced space. Seriously, what the ♥♥♥♥? That was a huge kick in the balls. At this point it becomes very obvious that they couldn't finish the rest of the game for whatever reason.

I'm only talking the negatives here because other reviews have highlighted the brighter side of the game: I particularly liked magic a lot, and that's what kept me playing the game. Still, I wouldn't recommend it unless you were really bored and had nothing else to play in your semi open-world RPG list (think Elder Scrolls, Witcher, some of Bioware's stuff)

reviewText: This game is really poor. It looks quite good, although the combat system is actually full of odd glitches (weird jumping, drowning horses, poor interaction with the terrain). The main problem is that the plot and quests are insanely stupid. They make no sense in driving the story forwards (just putting hurdles put in a player's way and making them jump over them) and generally make almost no sense even in the game's terms (like a riding race you need to win, which is witnessed by no-one and in the end the current holder of the title just accepts whatever you say - yeah
date:
sure I did it faster than you!"; except you're not allowed to say this until you do "win" the race).

I lost interest after about 10-15 hours and I won't go back to it.

reviewText:
It could be such a nice game...

+great crafting and character development
+not to boring combat system
+above average voice acting

BUT
-feels in more than one way unfinished
-ai sucks, tends to get stuck
-encountered countless graphic glitches, missing textures, ... oh and crashes! yay :(
-menues are a pain in the ♥♥♥ to use, no consistency at all
-even on easy i got my ♥♥♥ handed by random enemies, no indentication how powerfull something is... learn by dying
and even if you get to know some of the buggers it doesn't mean that in the next dungeon they are twice as vicious than before
-got stuck between rocks/debries/random stuff countless times... okay maybe it is not the ai but the leveldesign thats stupid
-handling is - in lack of a better description - clumpsy
my poor char is running in circles to get doors opened, i can't say how often i turned arround and fired a spell into oblivion instead of just stepping back. ohhh and riding! what a pleasure... if by any chance you get to face that ********** horse into the right direction you could enjoy... until the next rock... that is...

SHORTVERSION:
play skyrim again... or if you seek something new and dont mind wasting 2 bugs... give it at shot and weep at the potential wasted

reviewText:
Full disclosure: I got this in a past Humble Bundle, and thank god I did, because this isn't worth whatever I did pay for it, much less the price they're asking.

The graphics aren't bad, and the soundtrack, what I heard of it, is excellent, but who knows what the controls are and whoever designed it doesn't know things like how armor works and how to write an interesting story. The frankly awful DRM, which, while I understand their desire for demographic research and the ability to mail/email me promotions, I own this on Steam I've hardly stolen it, is just the cherry on top I'm afraid. I'm frankly not going to enter my CD key every time I play, especially not if I have to give some unknown thing a bunch of my personal information, including my physical address just to get the game I own out of demo mode. It's buggy and difficult to play (I got trapped halfway inside a gate three cutscenes in) and just, not that much fun.

I really, really wanted to like it. The cutscene martial arts look like something straight out of a Chinese Period drama, all slo mo and flying through the air and fancy tricks, on paper it has an interesting premise, but it needs some serious TLC before it'll be worth playing.

reviewText:
Understand that this is an action RPG that focuses on killing stuff, getting loot, and levelling up so you can kill more stuff.  If that appeals to you, go for it.  It appeals to me.
+ Very good graphics
+ Interesting character customization
+ Weapon/armor upgrades are fun and require some strategy
+ Combat system is relatively simple but fun
+ Places to go (open world!)
+ Lots of things to kill and kill and kill
+ Loot
+ Horse races!

Cons:
- A story so bad, it will leave you staring blankly into the distance for about an hour if you finish the game
- Possibly the *worst* voice-acting *ever* in any game of any kind.  Microsoft Sam would have been a better choice.
- Dialog is silly at best, incomprehensible at worst

reviewText:
Two Worlds II: Pirates of the Flying Fortress Expansion

Just to reconfirm the following covers my six hours invested in the Two Worlds II (Reality Pump should've been drug out into the street and shot for that title) expansion pack “Pirates of the Flying Fortress” and not the base game itself.

I am nowhere near the end of the expansion but after the amount of time invested I felt compelled to race in with good word before this game is lost to Steam's dungeon archives and forgotten all together.

Forget what you know about the first game in the series (Two Worlds). Although it wasn't entirely a bad entry in sandbox action/adventure games it mostly certainly left a lot of room for improvement which I feel was successfully implemented in the sequel (or at least its expansion).

Now, I must warn to not to do what I did – Which was skip to the expansion immediately without playing the base game first. I warn simply for the fact that your character's achievements and equipment are meant to carry over into the expansion from the base game. If you begin Flying Fortress not carrying over anything from TW2's base; Flying Fortress will start your character with far more than your character needs greatly reducing the challenge that Flying Fortress may have otherwise offered.

Not only did I find myself starting off with the best of the best there has been very little acquired during my six hours of play (Armour or Weapons) that improved on what I had.
And this game is Loot-Heavy! The looting element in Flying Fortress is on par with the obnoxious pack-ratting found in games like Torchlight so my mistake of starting the expansion first has pretty much killed a lot of the game's excitement during exploration.

I feel the best approach continuing onwards is to relay my experience in contrast to The Elder Scrolls games which you more than likely would've asked first and foremost. To summarize: Flying Fortress has sacrificed the massive scope of TES landscapes for a grand improvement of visuals. Reality Pump appears to have aimed for enclosing more relevant and interesting material into a smaller sandbox area. Teamed with very good optimization (modern day developers please look this word up it will help your efforts tremendously!) Flying Fortress plays like a much more aesthetically appealing Skyrim that cuts to the chase.

So if I could choose either Two Worlds II or Skyrim? Skyrim simply for the fact of hosting much more content and therefor longevity. Being able to afford both, however, it would be hypocrisy for TES fans to turn their noses up to Reality Pump's entry in sandbox action/adventure genre.

Price Recommended: $20 w/ Expansion

reviewText:
Ok graphics, good game mechanics and it's fun to play. However the voice acting is probably the worst I have ever heard in a game ever - it's like it was scripted and acted by someone with the emotional depth of a 10 year old. Your character is frankly quite creepy too since he often has a good laugh after killing animals.

I would have said that this was an ok buy if you get it for a dollar or two as I did but now having got half way through chapter one the game has started crashing frequently shortly after I summon a creature (this is on a relatively recent Mac BookPro). So at this point I'd not recommend it to anyone with a mac at any price - no clue whether it is more stable on windows.

reviewText:
This is my first review ever because Im lazy but I just had to write a review for this game because its so great.

If your reading this I know what your thinking, should I really buy this game? The answer is hell yes.

Im not gonna lie when it comes to the single player mode I only played about 5 minutes of it and I was disgusted with how awful it was lol. But the multiplayer omg so great.

The crafting of armor and crystals, and spells omg the possibilities of creation in this game is amazing. Everyone in multiplayer starts in a lobby town with shops and from there you pick missions, duels, ect. Its a great place to meet other players. If you enjoy variety and sklled combat this multiplayer experience is for you. Currently I'm rocking a Necromancer/poison mage and loving it. Its not a balanced system due to the almost limitless possbily of magic creation, yes you can make your own spells. That doesnt mean melee sucks, far from it. This game goes on sale all the time btw and is still very much alive, look for me LordRed Ill help you out online, unless your half dwarf....ew.

reviewText:
So I bought this expecting it to be a 3rd person Elder Scrolls knock-off, but the game I got was entirely different. I would probably describe it as more of a puzzler than anything else as I've faced many challenging mysteries during the short time I've played.

Why does it perform a first time set up every time I open it?
Why does the game need my postal address?
Why do my keyboard and mouse not work upon opening it two thirds of the time?
Will it ever acually connect and be able to register?

These are just some of the challenges you will face if you decide to get Two Worlds 2.

reviewText: This game is not even close to be a masterpiece however it is still worth a RPG fan's time. The main campaign is pretty long although it feels a bit rushed at the end. The main story is quite cliche and the A.I, pretty dumb. Playing archer while trying to complete every side quest allows you to oneshot pretty much every important boss. The entire game is just the masterpiece of mediocrity.\nHOWEVER the Pirates of Flying Fortress DLC is an insane improvement. A gameplay is still nothing special and fighint repetitive as hell, neverthless the plot is great, the voice acting and charachters are really sweat, endings are fairly touching (...yet they don't really care about your previous actions, you just have a single decision to make and that's it). I do recommend buying the game together with the DLC in some sale (I got both of them for like two (bucks), play the main campaign if you really have no better games in your sigh or skip it and start with this great DLC (although you will decide to do this you will face a very challanging game if you won't know the gameplay).\nOh, and the graphics are meh. Thankfuly the music has some hidden diamonds.

reviewText:
Got it because I enjoyed the original when I was younger. Have to say wasn't that impress by the campaign and I only managed to play two hours of it before quitting. The rest of the time however was spent playing the amazing multiplayer. Now it's noway near perfect but it's been hell of a fun time playing with friends.

You can create a character and play a fighter, mage, or ranger with various sub classes that specialise in sword and shield, two handed ect. which give you a starting bonus in those areas. When you create your character you proceed to choose a hub server to join. These hub servers" (as I'll call them because I actually haven't played in a while and a have forgot what they're called. :P) are a place where you can buy equipment and socialise with other players. From here you create/join groups and head off to play.

Multiplayer missions are pretty good when playing with friends
date: some can take a couple of hours to complete but they are entertaining to do.\n\nIf it's on sale for over 75% off
recommended: get it if you like action-y RPG's that you can play with your friends. ;)"
