reviewText:
Single Player
Very slow paced, slow traveling and there isn't anything really special or interesting besides the ability to craft spells, which some spells can be quite hilarious, but that fun factor is short lived. Also, there is no way to change time or fast foward time (i.e. Elder Scrolls games you can wait or sleep till the sun rises), so if you made it to a town and its night time where shops are closed and people are locked up in their homes you have to... leave the game running or explore.. or something till the sun rises. Lockpicking and pickpocketing is by little minigames that gets old fast. I can't bring myself to continue playing single player mode at all after an hour or two.

Multi Player
Non-shared loot can get frustrating if you are not playing with friends. A little more fast paced than single player with a lot of mobs to kill to keep you busy, and the extra mobs to help you level up faster. If you party with lots of people who like to summon mobs it will turn into a sh*tfest quickly. Also no more than 2 melee summoned creature per target; the rest of your summons will stand still and do nothing blocking other players since you can't walk through mobs.  There are different types of Multiplayer settings, I spent most of it on Adventure playing with a friend. I randomly disconnected and saw I was accused of using a trainer and got temp banned. I was low level and poor with little to no equipment upgrades, a lot of empty accessories (no gems), ran away from a bunch of mobs, while using lots of health potions and half dying all the time with my friend. There are better games to grind that have a much larger community (say ~50 players max online/ingame).

BTW I didn't have any problems with registering (I have a router + firewall) and only gave general information (don't think they have to be true either).


tl;dr
Bought this game on sale for ~$5 including a DLC.
Don't bother with this game unless you have friends to play with in multiplayer and at the really low price I got it for.
4/10 (+2 sale price, +2 magic crafting system).

reviewText:
Two Worlds II is another one of those promising games that take you absolutely nowhere.

Gameplay is pretty solid, a 7/10 to say the least, combat feels good and responsive, actions are quickly performed, movement is smooth and you won't feel like it takes four hours to walk from point A to point B, even though the game world is large enough. There is a decent amount of habilities, magic spells, weapons and armors to buy and upgrade, but they are bound to level, meaning that they'll only appear on the game world once you reach a certain level, so if you want to relive the thrill of finding that overpowered legendary item in a chest deep down a cave full of perilous monsters, forget that. All you're gonna get are some lockpicks, a medium healing potion and a wizard's hat. And that is if you're a warrior. 'Cause if you play a mage, the game will make sure that there's a warrior helm in that chest, just so you won't be able to use what you find, a very common issue in modern RPGs.

The game world is pretty large, composed of some three major islands, each one of them themed around something like middle-east, asian, and european designs of builduings, flora and fauna. There are plenty of quests to be done and there's a fair amount of NPCs, but none of them are memorable or even good at all. You're going to do a lot of running around, a little bit of riding around on a horse and even less sailing around, because you only get a boat too ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ late, and that is another issue with modern RPGs. What the ♥♥♥♥ is wrong with giving the player a ship from the start, so he or she can have some fun sailing around the islands? Anyway, It seems like there's a lot to do, but there isn't, really.

Which brings us to the last point of this review and, by far, the worst thing in this game, not to mention the reason for me to not recomend Two Worlds II to anyone: The game suffers from a all-too-common rushed ending. The first major island will take you quite a long time to complete, since there's a lot to do and see. The second one, a little bit less. The third you can almost skip completely, since there's very little to do on it. The plot is also extremely rushed, with a huge deus ex machina right at the ending, throwing everything you've been doing on the main quest since the start out of the window.

All in all, this game dosen't deserve more than a 5/10 and I would only recomend it if you, like me, have played pretty much every other RPG on existence. You might have some fun with it, but you would probably rather play something else instead.

Gameplay - 8/10
Soundtrack - 6/10
Graphics - 7/10
Content - 4/10
Challenge Level - 5/10
Replayability - 3/10

reviewText: WARNING: This review may contain what some people might see as minor spoilers"....\n\nThe Two Worlds II Game is a great RPG game that has a lot of adventure game like elements in it
date: I think it will appeal most to PC game players that likes to use character to run around and explore and do a lot of battles along the way. For full enjoyment of the the game I must recommend using a Game Pad such as the Logitech F510/F710 or similar. The game offers large maps to explore and if one prefers one can simply roam the maps and gather loot and ressources taken fromn enemies
hoursPlayed: plants or found in maze like caves
voteText: chests or if skill good enough from places in buildings entered by picking locks or getting money from gambling or pickpocketing (both difficult unless high skill or great luck) - of course one can also get new objects both through quest and trade and one can trade objects/loot away also. High Lock picking skill is a must in this game. Also don't overlook that you can also scroll on teleportation maps so that you can travel to previous locations.\n\nA prominent feature is also the ability to
helpfulPercent: after breaking down loot into elemental components
votesHelpful:
being able to combine components and to upgrade items (both demanding aquired and spent skill points for abilities). Though the player have a map of locations then in some cases in can be difficult to find a few of the locations (or to get there).

The game is to large extend non-linear but as it is story driven one ofcourse must perform some tasks to unlock other tasks or possibility of access to places...

I have played the game for more than 200 hours and I have yet to finish the expansion. But with repspect to the Two Worlds II base game itself then I think that there were only two things that really sucked for me.

One is that one at a time gets the task to have to participate in a horse race to advance in game and that can be rather difficult for many (however one can cheat by placing personal teleportation stones in advance and use these to get around
votesTotal:
this will leave you with map markers that won't go away but at least will solve the horse race problem)(Placing of personal teleportation stones on selected places on some maps will help the player a lot getting around with greater ease).

The other thing is the final "boss" battle which in my taste is too difficult...

But all in all the Two Worlds II game will offer many hours of entertaining game play for those liking the genre and style that this particular game offers.

Personaly I think it is a great game that I will recommend other people to try if it appeals to you through the description given...
"

reviewText:
I'll admit that I didn't even make my way out of the starting area before being put off.  The entire game world felt wooden; awkwardly imposed cut scenes and voice acting, being restricted to a 'demo version' unless I 'registered' the game with personal details and a slight swaying of the camera when the PC runs (I've never been sea-sick before, but I'd imagine this game will cause nausea in some).  Maybe they take more time to accustom to, but the controls also seemed iffy: I tried jumping from a staircase, but had to try a few times before managing to succeed.

Seeing the positive reviews on here there's probably more to this game, but there's something about two worlds that just makes me want to hate it; right down to the big bad who's outraged by his prisoner escaping, but is too busy to walk over and stop it.  Maybe if I'm bored some day I'll give it another shot, but I certainly wouldn't recommend anyone purchase the game.

Edit: maybe it was an intentional part of the tutorial/escape sequence, but the AI seemed awful.  I was chased by a swarm of guards, then ran back past them a few times.  None of them could attack me unless I stood still.

reviewText: Unlike most I was actually a big fan of the first Two Worlds and this was one of the few games I actually bought when it was released as opposed to waiting for it to go on sale.  Encounters can prove difficult at the start of the game and taking on more than one foe at once isn't always wise.  Once you're on par with the local wildlife at the start of the game is when Two Worlds 2 really starts to take off.  It's easy to forget about the storyline as you get sucked into all of the side quests that really seem to propel the game more than the story but it's just too much fun to stop.  I find nothing more enjoyable than venturing off into the distance just to find out what's there, destroying whatever stands in my way, and gearing myself along the way.  This game just keeps it coming like a 50 hour IV.

reviewText:
Two Worlds II is a fun Action RPG for fans of the genre, with some interesting customization ideas that make it stand out from other RPGs of similar quality. If you are a Warrior or a Ranger, you strengthen your equipment by Blacksmithing and Gems, if you are a Mage, you craft your spells by combining property cards into amulets and using them through a staff, and in any of the cases, you can Dye your armor in various colours or take advantage of Alchemy to brew special Potions.

The game is precisely reminiscent of The Witcher, both in being a 3rd person Action RPG with customizations, and in the Main Protagonist, whose style of humor and even his voice, may remind you of Geralt of Rivia.

On the down side, the game does suffer from quite a few bugs in specific quests and some things may also look unpolished. And typically, the ending may feel dissappointing depending on the player.

reviewText:
Surprisingly pleasant.

While it may appear to be a Diablo clone it is far from it.  The combat is in-depth (far from a click fest) and the magic system is one of the very best I have ever seen (if not the very best).  The customization of melee choices and magical choices, with the combat, multiplayer, AND ability to build a village of my own puts this close to, if not above, Skyrim.

reviewText:
After two playthroughs as a warrior first and mage second I can say it is MUCH more rewarding to play this game as a mage. The spell system is first class, with the card system allowing you to make your own spells, with almost limitless potential. Add more cards to make it more powerful but cost more mana, add modifier cards that effect the way the spell works, such as a firebolt homing in on the target, splitting into more than one bolt (add more cards get more splits!), add a card that makes it ricochet off the target etc. The feeling you get when you finally get that spell to work that fires a frostbolt that splits, and summons a creature where every split hits. or that heals you when it hits is great. You feel like a mage testing his own spells and crafting exactly what works for you.

Pros to the game for me included: Graphics are still amazing even being almosted 3 years old, the lock picking mini game is enjoyable and requires some skill, and you get a lot of bang for your buck in that the main story is relatively long (1 1/2 playthroughs netted me over 60 hours, mainly just doing the main questline and whatever side quests I happened to bump into). As the game progresses I found all the creatures still gave decent challenges, there was no level of gear or skills I obtained that made me one shot all the mobs. I am sure though, that there is some derivative spell I missed that can do this if you can find it :)

Minor cons for me included the amount of cut scenes and dialogue. You will spend a lot of your time listening to the charactors talk. At higher levels you can also summon a lot of creatures that your charactor doesn't clip through, and when you are not in combat, they crowd around you. I found far to often that I had to stand and wait the 60 secs for them to despawn before I could move as they had boxed me in. I also had a lot of random crashes, mainly during cut scenes, the game would hang and would need to be shut down and restarted.

The major con I have with this game is the final boss fight. Most RPG's, and this one is no different, require you to level, increase skills to take on harder challenges as the game progresses. Imagine my surprise when I discovered all those spells that gave me fuzzy feelings when I finally got them to work were absolutely useless, as you do not fire one spell at the boss. All the potions I had crafted were useless, resistance potions had no effect on the damage I took, damage potions had no effect on the damage I dealt (as you don't cast spells at the boss). Reflect and shield spells I had crafted had no impact on damage taken either. Only the health pots were usable (and I went through a few of them). All the time finding the best gear, upgrading it, adding crystals useless as well. I found this out as I decided to respec to add a lot more health at the expense of damage, but the damage I took was the same, as it appears to be a % of your health.

All in all apart from this, Two Worlds II provides an enjoyable experience, fun spell system, and deep, though not very original story. As it seems to come on sale a fair bit, paying $15, or $7.50 for it is well worth it, but I also think it is worth the time full price.

reviewText: Two Worlds was almost universally reviled when it was released. Two Worlds II, as a result, was kind of... ignored. I feel that was a mistake. The game is actually pretty cool! A big open world, filled with weird stuff to do and find, some interesting dialogue and story hooks, and some pretty nifty graphics to look at while you're doin' all that. It's a little clunky, and the main character sounds like a jerk, but on the whole, it's probably worth at least trying out. It certainly doesn't deserve to be looked down on. 4/5

reviewText:
Two worlds 2, I was a bit worried about getting this one when i was looking for a rpg to play because of the bad energy the first recieved. However it came in a bundle deal for only about $7 and I say Iv'e definatly got my moneys worth. Sure some animations may be a bit clunky (however improves a bit with the dlc) the conenct itself is a real good time. At first things feel real strong against you with being 2-3 shot with the block being very strange mechanic only blocking a small amount of damage at the start and your shields do block projectiles but its more for apperance than anything you cant actualy raise to block.

This being said the Progression system in this game made me love it especially spell crafting, using heaps of different combinations to make your own spell is pretty awsome(like anvil tornado or spraying projectiles with summoning).

If your willing to overcome its buggyness to get use to the games many unique systemes(sailing for dlc, magic crafting) and want a rpg to kill alot of hours I reccomend go for it.

Also if anyone know any other action/rpg or anything where you can sail id appreciate it

reviewText:
Two Worlds II is an RPG from Reality Pump Studios. You start out the emperor's prisoner, but are quickly freed. Your major goal is to disrupt the emperor's plans and defeat him, bringing the land back to peace. Overall, it's a worthwhile play if you like RPGs. However, the game has a number of shortcomings that may not make it enjoyable for you. (Note: I did not play any multiplayer games, so I can't comment on that).

PROS
-Tons of quests, which keeps the player engaged with the game. Main storyline is good overall, and there are a few twists along the way and at the end.
-Beautiful graphics, scenery, and locations, all throughout the game. Many good environments/settings.
-Unique and customizable magic system. In brief, through the combination of element cards (fire, water, etc.), carrier cards (e.g., summon, bolt) and modifier cards (e.g., damage, ricochet), you create spells. Tons of possibilities and combinations.
-The crafting system is also different, but good. Here, crafting means upgrading your weapons and armor and adding crystals. Break down your old or unused weapons/armor in order to create the upgrade materials, so nothing goes to waste.
-Going along with the previous two points, there are tons of ingredients for potions. Can spend hours trying out different combinations to produce the most powerful effects.
-Leveling up focuses on developing skills, so you can tailor your skill set to your playstyle accordingly.
-Can have up to three active armor/weapon sets at once, which are easily switched to with the press of a button. For example, I had equipment set up for a warrior with sword/shield, a warrior with 2h hammer, and a mage.
-I've seen people complain about the voice acting, but I thought it was okay and brought the game to life a bit more. Same goes for the dialogue itself. The cutscenes throughout the game were generally great and helped move the story along.

CONS
-While the storyline is fine, it isn't set up well. There was no recap of the first Two Worlds, so you're just thrown into it with no real explanation of why Gandohar is bad and how you were imprisoned.
-Inventory management is terrible. Weapons/armor do not stack, so even if you kill a bunch of Varns and have 12 of the same exact sword, they show up as 12 different items. So when you break them down into crafting materials, you do it one sword at a time. Quite tedious. You cannot purchase multiple items (like potions) at once. Potion ingredients are not grouped by effect, and you cannot reorder any items. Despite being able to have three equipment sets, when looking at equipment, only the currently active items are highlighted; there is no indication which items are being used in other sets, which is problematic when selling and crafting.
-Crafting system is a major strength of the game, but when upgrading weapons/armor, you have to wait 5-8 seconds for it to finish upgrading before doing it again. Can only upgrade one level at a time, even if you possess enough material for 10 upgrades. In other words, it's tedious.
-I did not like some of the gameplay elements. Sometimes I was standing directly in front of a chest, and it would not register so I couldn't open it until I moved one or two steps to the right or left. Riding around on a horse is frustrating; I didn't bother after the horse race quest. The camera always wanted to zoom in, and I like playing with it zoomed out, so I was constantly adjusting it.
-The final boss battle was pretty blah.
-The Pirates of the Flying Fortress DLC starts out promising, but ends up being 7+ hours of fetch quests. I'm glad it came with my initial purchase and that I did not spend any extra money on it.

OVERALL
-Tends to be an engrossing game, but the shortcomings (most of which center on playability) do make it frustrating at times. I feel like the game did the bigger things well (graphics, settings, quests, crafting), but the little things poorly. If RPGs are your thing, you'll find it worth your time. Otherwise, skip it.

reviewText:
Two Worlds II is a solid, if a bit generic, single person RPG.  I have seen comparisons to Skyrim/Elder Scrolls games and will say that I think that is somewhat of an unfair bar with which to compare it.  I played the original Two Worlds and found this to retain some of the nice features of the original (making all materials usable, the ability  to tailor weapons to work best against specific foes) while dumping some of the lesser features (the horse combat, which, while a neat idea, never worked well). The ability to tailor the character skills to my style of play was a definite plus to the game, allowing me to make the character I wanted as opposed to following a class type.  The main storyline was decent, but the side quests, while sometimes fun, were rather generic.
I found the exploration in this game to be rather limited.  Although there were several places the hero could go immediately, there wasn't much to discover at each location.  I was also somewhat disappointed to find that the last island, while seemingly huge on the map, was very limited in where the character could go.
I actually found the Pirates of the Flying Fortress expansion to be more enjoyable than the main game.  Although the gameplay was very similar, I felt the plot that was more absorbing for me (perhaps it is my deep-seated longing to be a pirate of old).  The humor was great and the side quests seemed more engrossing than the main game.
All in all, I can recommend this game when purchased at a discount for someone who is looking for something familiar and somewhat generic to waste a bit of time and follow a story.  I would recommend against it for someone looking for a cutting edge game that has something new (or, had something new 3 years ago).

I bought two worlds 2 out of complete boredom yesterday while it was on say for £3.50 or something and i wasnt blown away by anything.

This game is good.. but things do cause it to not be one of the best. The story line so far is ok. Its not brilliant and breathtaking.. but neither was Skyrims main quests? If you look past the dull story and the painfully bad animations on characters (when they talk their faces dont move, they are late to move their arms and the dude runs like a ♥♥♥♥♥) then its an alright RPG to sit back and play. It allows you to escape to another world and have a decent time.
I wouldnt pay the full price for this game but its not too bad.
I'd give it a 3.5/5 in total. Not crap but not the best.

reviewText:
After 24 hrs here is my thoughts....

Pros:
Nice to look at.
Open world, large open enviroments to explore.
Magic system is interesting.
Crafting is simple and effective.
Has a good dose of humour.
It doesnt make things too easy - you can stumble into places and get a shock (reminded of Morrowind a bit)

Cons:
Melee combat isnt great. You can play a melee (in fact i am cos i just dont do mages) but you feel like your thrashing about more than tactically fighting. Once you learn that you can easily get behind larger beasties it gets easier.
Some of the resistances on mobs are not obvious (dunno if im just missing something but the manual tells you sod all ).
After 24hrs i still dont know what some of the stats on weapons mean. Nothing in the manual.

Basically, its a pretty good solid action rpg with a nice world and decent visuals. If some of the finer points were more obvious, ie stats it would be better but this is not going to ruin the game.
If you enjoy the likes of Skyrim and you see this in a sale then for sub £5 you will get alot of gameplay and some decent RPG hack n slash.

reviewText:
I had not played the first Two Worlds but the second one is great. I needed a decent RPG and Two Worlds 2 gave me that. Main character's cast is great and also other NPC's are awesome too, especially Dar Pha.

The story and campaigne system is well built but the side quests aren't so. Nearly all of the side quests consist of slaying monsters, thats all. So, after the first chapter the side quest start to become boring.

The soundtracks of hte game are great but in lots of situations the music unexpectedly stops immediately on you have to play game without music, it is really not cool.

The RPG elements are scarce but since I'd love Gothic series, Two Worlds 2 gave me what I wanted.

If you are searcing a little one-way RPG but great action you should try Two Worlds 2 (but I can not the say the same for the DLC, hence other than the ending it's complete waste of time).

reviewText:
Two Worlds II is a solid, if a bit generic, single person RPG.  I have seen comparisons to Skyrim/Elder Scrolls games and will say that I think that is somewhat of an unfair bar with which to compare it.  I played the original Two Worlds and found this to retain some of the nice features of the original (making all materials usable, the ability  to tailor weapons to work best against specific foes) while dumping some of the lesser features (the horse combat, which, while a neat idea, never worked well). The ability to tailor the character skills to my style of play was a definite plus to the game, allowing me to make the character I wanted as opposed to following a class type.  The main storyline was decent, but the side quests, while sometimes fun, were rather generic.
I found the exploration in this game to be rather limited.  Although there were several places the hero could go immediately, there wasn't much to discover at each location.  I was also somewhat disappointed to find that the last island, while seemingly huge on the map, was very limited in where the character could go.
I actually found the Pirates of the Flying Fortress expansion to be more enjoyable than the main game.  Although the gameplay was very similar, I felt the plot that was more absorbing for me (perhaps it is my deep-seated longing to be a pirate of old).  The humor was great and the side quests seemed more engrossing than the main game.
All in all, I can recommend this game when purchased at a discount for someone who is looking for something familiar and somewhat generic to waste a bit of time and follow a story.  I would recommend against it for someone looking for a cutting edge game that has something new (or, had something new 3 years ago).
